For over sixty years, the pianist Alfred Brendel became a leading figure in classical music. He was known for being serious and intellectual, focusing on important European piano works. Although he wrote and performed a lot, he taught very few students. Those who knew him saw a playful side, but this was rarely shown in his concerts. His life was a constant cycle of studying, traveling, and performing.

About four or five years ago, a young boy named Kit Armstrong came to one of Brendel’s concerts and asked for lessons. At first, Brendel did not take this request seriously. He had very few students and did not see a reason to start teaching now. He quoted another famous pianist, saying, “You don’t hire a mountain guide to teach a child how to walk.” However, he was impressed by Kit, who was around 14 years old at the time. Brendel listened to him play and said, “He played remarkably well and from memory. Then he gave me a CD of a recital he had performed, and I thought, ‘I have to make time for him.’ It was a performance that connected beautifully from start to finish. It’s rare to find a musician with such understanding and subtlety.”

As Brendel steps back from the public eye, Kit is starting to make his own way in the music world. Kit, now 19, is always busy, learning new languages, studying math, writing computer code, or playing tennis, all while his mother keeps a close watch on him. He also composes music. Brendel says, “This is very important. Learning to read music is easier when you try to write your own. I noticed that Kit has an amazing memory and is a great sight reader. More importantly, he listens to his own playing and understands what I explain to him. When I tell him something about a piece, he applies it throughout the entire piece.”

Brendel is careful not to raise expectations. He gets upset when newspapers call Kit the future great pianist of the 21st century, saying, “That’s the worst thing to say. It can cause a lot of harm. Like many talented young musicians, he can play some pieces incredibly well, while others need more time and practice. It would be unfair for a critic to expect perfection.”

Now at 80 years old, Brendel shows a softer side in his retirement. He explains, “When I was young, I didn’t want to be famous quickly, but I hoped to achieve certain things by the age of 50. When I turned 50, I felt I had accomplished most of those goals, but I still wanted to do more, so I continued. Although I don’t have the physical strength I once had, my mind is always active with many pieces I’ve never played. I don’t perform now, but I enjoy this new phase of my career.”

Text: "When I was a child, I thought gardens were beautiful places. My Grandad’s garden was by a river and sloped gently down to the water. You couldn’t reach the river, but you could hear the water and the birds in the trees. I believed all gardens were like this – peaceful and quiet. Grandad’s garden was simple. He didn’t have a fancy greenhouse like some neighbors. Their greenhouses were made from old window frames, with plastic covering broken glass.

At home, my father was often quiet. He had a sense of humor and enjoyed silly things. He liked to say, ‘It’s immaterial to me,’ instead of just saying ‘I don’t mind.’ Deep down, he might have felt disappointed with his life. He left school without qualifications and became a plumber, which he didn’t love. He wasn’t very ambitious, although he and my mother once thought about moving to Canada, but it didn’t happen. He was good at fixing things around the house, whether it was bookshelves or cupboards.

My parents only moved house once, but my mother loved changing the furniture. Just when you got used to one chair, another would appear. The biggest change was when a piano arrived. I wanted to like it, but it felt intimidating. I only liked the two brass candlesticks on it. My mother thought they were too fancy, and they disappeared while I was at school. I was never allowed to play the piano; my sister took lessons instead. When I asked my mother why I didn’t get the chance, she simply said, ‘You’d never have practiced.’

Of the three places to explore – moors, woods, or river – I always chose the river. I could imagine another world there. With a fishing net over my shoulder and old sandals on my feet, I would walk along the riverbank looking for a good spot to take off my sandals and have a picnic. I would carefully look through the water for fish to catch, but after failing to keep them alive in the backyard, I returned them to the river.

I wanted to leave school as soon as possible, but it seemed unlikely until one day my father said, ‘There’s a job for an apprentice gardener in the Parks Department. I thought you might be interested.’ In that moment, he went against his usual thoughts. He might have preferred if I became a carpenter, but I like to think that deep down, he hoped things would turn out well for me if I worked hard. Maybe I’m wrong, but I believe that even though he didn’t like gardening, he saw my enthusiasm for it and appreciated my passion for plants and flowers."

Lawrence MacEwen is crouching down on his Scottish island, the Isle of Muck. I am doing the same. A strong wind from the Atlantic threatens to blow us off the steep cliff at our feet and into the ocean below. MacEwen’s sheepdog, Tie, comes close, and his owner gently strokes him. Despite the howling wind, MacEwen feels comfortable on his island, where he belongs. 

MacEwen shows me around his neighborhood. He points to the north and shouts, “That island is Eigg. The one to the west is the Isle of Rum, which gets twice as much rain as we do.” I see dark clouds pouring rain on Rum’s tall mountains. “Just beyond Rum is the island of Soay.” 

Suddenly, MacEwen says, “I have sheep to move,” as rain starts to come our way. We walk down the slopes, and he shares some facts about the island: Volcanic Muck is three kilometers long and one and a half kilometers wide; its geese eat a lot of grass; and the MacEwen family has lived here for 3,000 years. 

While herding the sheep, Tie is not doing a good job. “Away to me, Tie. Away to me,” means the dog should go to the right, but he goes straight through the flock, causing confusion. “Tie,” MacEwen says with disappointment. The dog looks ashamed. 

The Isle of Muck is mostly run by the MacEwen family. Lawrence and his wife, Jenny, run the farm; their son Colin manages the island cottages; and their daughter Mary runs the island hotel, Port Mor, with her husband, Toby. Mary and Toby enjoy that their two boys can explore the island and sail small boats in the summer. “They go out the door and come back only when they’re hungry.” 

However, life on the island has its challenges. For example, electricity is only available part of the time. On my first evening, I wait for the lights to turn on. The next morning, I find Mary preparing breakfast by torchlight. I also have to deal with no mobile phone service. “There is reception on the hill,” Mary tells me. “Most people last a couple of days, then just put the phone away.” So I do the same. 

Everything on Muck feels wonderfully surprising. A boat arrives today with groceries and three musicians who come off carrying instruments. Their concert in the island’s tearoom is a big success, with the islanders tapping their feet to the music. 

That night, sitting by a warm fire while it rains outside, Lawrence MacEwen tells me how he met his wife, Jenny. “Her father saw a small farm on the isle of Soay in a newspaper and bought it without even visiting. He had never been to Scotland. Jenny was sent to manage it.” Did Jenny know how to run a farm? “She had good typing skills.” 

I go to bed listening to the rain and wake up to more rain. But I eat well, as almost all my food comes from the island. Mary sends me to fisherman Sandy Mathers for fresh fish. I carry it back through the village and give it to Mary at the kitchen door. By 7 pm, our fish is on the table, and it is delicious. 

The next morning, I worry about my ferry ride to the next island. Many ferries had been canceled in the past two months because of rough seas. If my ferry doesn’t come, I would be stuck on Muck for two more days, which, secretly, I would not mind at all.

Text: 

The game design industry was once mostly made up of computer scientists and self-taught individuals. It used to be seen as just a hobby for young people, but now it is taken seriously. This change may surprise some, but experts in the industry are not surprised. However, getting into this field is not easy. Creating video games based on new movies requires many team members and a lot of skill and hard work. Like many industries, it can be hard to enter, but it is growing.

Jim Donelly, a spokesperson for an online games magazine, says, "It is very difficult to make progress in big companies or to influence major games. But the industry needs game designers now more than ever. They need not just top-level directors but also those who design systems and individual parts of the game."

So, how can you enter this competitive industry? Many companies prefer candidates with a degree in computer science, but Jim has a different opinion. He believes, "The only way is to make games. The tools are available. You won’t get a job if you haven’t created something, and you won’t succeed on your own if you are not making things. Game design is more than just a job; it is a way of life. Like any creative work, it must be done to be real."

Another expert, John Field, agrees but adds that it is more complicated. "There are many people who want to work in games, but few meet the industry's requirements today. Even fewer have the creativity, technical skills, vision, and business sense needed to contribute to this changing field." 

Can you succeed on your own? John says, "Maybe, but it is quite difficult. A good postgraduate course in games can help and provide support and guidance. Most game designers start as programmers or artists and work their way up. They are interested in all types of entertainment and have a strong interest in the arts and modern culture. They may have worked for a few years after graduation but have realized that games are their passion. They are not just fans; they are excited about the future of games and understand the growing variety in this field. 

Connections can also help. This is often ignored, but to succeed in games, as in many other areas, you need to network." The old image of a young boy playing video games has changed. Now, games attract a wider audience, including families who play on interactive consoles. Smartphones also offer many new games through apps and social media. John believes there is a lot of potential for growth. "Games have become popular among larger audiences. They are also a great way to learn, and I see this area as full of new possibilities and opportunities."

Text: "Since I was a child, I have always wanted to play football. My dad encouraged me to play, but he never forced me, and I appreciate that. I had a friend whose dad was very strict about football. He always told him what he could and couldn’t do. My friend could have been a good player, but he lost interest and stopped playing. I’m glad that didn’t happen to me, but I know it could have been different. When I score a great goal from far away, people often say it’s just luck, but it’s not. I have practiced taking long shots since I was young. You can only score amazing goals by practicing. The best players in the world have natural talent, but they also practice for many years. Sometimes young players collide on the field, but I learned the right techniques. When I teach kids, I always tell them to enjoy learning new skills. 

At school, I played many sports, from rounders and baseball to athletics and basketball. I know now that a good education is important, but back then, football was my main focus. The teachers were doing a good job, but I didn’t realize it at the time. I want my son to have a different experience. We are already trying to read him books, even though he is too young to sit still for long. I hope he doesn’t just want to kick the books around like I did. 

At the start of my professional football career, the manager made sacrifices so that younger players like us could join the first team, but he never made a big deal about it. He didn’t gather us and say, ‘This is your big chance,’ but we all knew it was. I scored in the first game of the season, but we lost. A famous TV presenter said, ‘You can’t win anything with kids,’ which made us realize how much we needed to improve. We had some doubts, but we believed in ourselves as a team despite his words. 

I rely a lot on my close friends and family. However, having money can sometimes create problems. For example, people often ask me why I let my mother keep working. I have helped my parents financially; I paid off their house loan and bought them a car last Christmas. My family is strong, and I think they would be upset if they felt they should depend on me. My mom doesn’t earn much as a hairdresser, but she loves her job. On the other hand, I enjoy using my money to help those around me. I have a lot of money, but not as much as people think, and it doesn’t solve all my problems. 

After I stop playing, I plan to take a year off or even longer to do things I haven’t been able to do. I want to go skiing the day after I stop playing. I can’t do that now because if I break a leg while skiing and can’t play football again, I wouldn’t be insured."

Text: 'Sam Carter was the reason we lived at Reef Point. He was my father’s agent in Los Angeles. My father was having a hard time writing there, so Sam offered to help us find a cheap place to live. The beach was usually empty because the sun was often covered by sea fogs. Reef Point did not attract many visitors. The road was not very inviting, and a nicer resort called La Carmella was nearby, so most people chose to go there instead. Only those who were broke or really loved surfing would come to Reef Point. 

But now, with the hot weather, many people were at the beach. After being alone for months, we were surrounded by activity. My father was busy trying to finish a script, and he was very stressed. I often went to the beach with a book and my dog, Rusty. When we first moved to Reef Point, we didn’t have a dog, but Rusty started hanging around. I tried to send him away, but he kept coming back. One morning, I felt sorry for him and gave him some water. My father threw a boot at him, but he didn’t really mean it. Rusty knew this and came closer. I asked my father, ‘Who does he belong to?’ My father replied, ‘He thinks we belong to him.’

Rusty loved the beach and liked to dig things up and bring them to me. Sometimes he found things that didn’t belong to him, like a new sneaker or a bright beach towel, and I had to return them. He also loved to swim and always wanted to join me, even though I could swim faster. We had been swimming that day. My father had gone to Los Angeles to deliver his script, so Rusty and I spent the afternoon together in the sea. As the sun began to set, it got cooler, and we watched the surfers. They had been surfing all day and didn’t seem to get tired. One surfer caught my attention. She was very skilled and made the others look clumsy. When she decided to stop, she rode in on a final wave.

“Hi,” she said, “why didn’t you join us?” 
“I don’t have a surfboard.” 
“You could get one.” 
“I don’t have any money.” 
“You’re British, right? Are you visiting?” 
“No, I live here.” 
“Is your father American?” 
“No. He came here to write a film script based on a novel he wrote.” 
“Really? What’s his name?” 
“Rufus Marsh.” 
“Do you mean ‘Tall as the Morning’?” I nodded. 
“I read that book from start to finish.” 

She looked at me with new interest, and I realized that people were friendly but only showed real interest when I mentioned my father’s book, 'Tall as the Morning.'”

Text: 

"What have I done?" Violet Hetherington thought to herself. She was standing in a long line at the dock in Southampton, waiting to board the Queen Caroline. The line was spilling out of the area marked ‘Departures’, and no one was moving. Her friend Annie had told her, "It's best to get to the docks late. If you arrive too early, you’ll just be waiting around." Annie, who was married to a diplomat and had traveled a lot, usually gave good advice. But this time, she was wrong.

After a while, an announcement came over the loudspeakers: there was a problem with the computer system. The mood among the waiting passengers became tense. Some tried to stay patient, while others attempted to make jokes, but most people were unhappy. They had paid a lot of money for this trip, and it was supposed to be a special experience. The fact that they couldn’t board the ship quickly made things worse. Violet felt like leaving. 

She reached into her bag for her phone but realized it was missing. This was more frustrating than the long wait. It made her feel like taking this cruise was a mistake. Now, without her phone, she couldn’t call the taxi company to see if she had left it in the cab, because all the important numbers were saved in her phone. This was the kind of mistake her older son, Harry, always warned her about.

Behind her in the line was a friendly-looking couple. "I’m sorry, but I think I left my mobile phone behind. Could I borrow yours to make a quick call?" Violet asked. She called Harry using their phone and left a message asking him to check with her neighbor, Kristina, to see if the phone was at home. If it wasn’t, she would be in trouble because she had no other way to find the numbers she needed in New York. Part of her thought, "Thank goodness," but she didn’t tell Harry that. Harry believed he was more experienced than his mother, while her younger son, Daniel, was more understanding of her mistakes because he made them too. Dan might forget to pass the message to Kristina.

Eventually, the line started to move, and Violet reached a window where she handed over her travel documents and prepared to board. Her heart sank when she entered the ship’s foyer, which looked like a cheap hotel trying too hard to impress. There were shiny fake wood panels, fancy chandeliers, polished brass, and carpets that looked like those in airports. 

Violet followed the signs to the ‘Elevators’, which were covered in mirrors and filled with tired passengers. They might have preferred not to see their reflections after a long morning of travel. Violet was squeezed against the side of the lift as it moved up, stopping at each floor to let people out. Finally, on the twelfth floor, she stepped out and felt free. Thankfully, her room had the balcony she had requested. She had been worried about what to say if it didn’t. Ignoring Annie’s advice to wait for a last-minute deal, she had decided to pay the highest price she could afford to ensure she had a good view of the sea.

When John Maloof bought a box of old photo negatives at an estate auction, he had no idea he was about to discover the mystery of Vivian Maier. Maloof was looking for pictures to include in a book about the Portage Park neighborhood in Chicago, USA. Instead, he found 30,000 images taken by Maier, a street photographer known for her amazing ability to capture interesting moments. Since then, Maloof has built a collection of Maier’s life and work. In his home, he keeps her cameras, 2,000 rolls of film, 3,000 prints, and 100,000 negatives, along with many 8mm movies and audiotapes. 

One morning, Maloof looked around at all this and realized he was on the edge of something special, which happened by chance. “When I bought all this, I had no idea what it was,” Maloof said. “I’m a third-generation flea market seller and could have easily sold it all to someone else.” For a while, Maloof and his friend Anthony Rydzon have been trying to learn more about Maier’s life. They reached out to families who had hired her as a nanny and spoke with people from the shop where she developed her film. 

Maier was born in 1926 in New York and spent much of her childhood in France. In 1951, she returned to New York and moved to Chicago in 1956 to work as a nanny. Maier was known to be a private person but had a unique personality. She always carried a camera with her and wore large coats, wide-brimmed hats, and sturdy shoes. “On her day off, the camera would be around her neck, and we wouldn’t see her again until late at night,” said Maren Baylaender, whose husband employed Maier to care for his daughter. “I remember her as a private person but one who had strong opinions about movies and politics.” 

Maier was knowledgeable about theater and films. Although she was not very social, she would walk the streets with her camera and talk to people, some of whom she interviewed on audiotape. She seemed to be very dedicated to her “second job” of documenting the world around her. “She was a true artist who followed her dreams,” said Rydzon. “She didn’t let anyone or anything stop her.” 

Maier’s work is a pure form of art; she did not create it for money. Her images often focus on women, children, the elderly, the poor, and abstract subjects. “What is interesting about Vivian is that she has so many captivating pictures,” said photography expert Larry Silverman. He sees influences from other photographers in her work and wonders if she developed her own style or borrowed ideas from others. 

Maloof often thinks about whether he will ever go through all the negatives, which he keeps in three tall, fireproof file cabinets. The funny thing is that he had no real interest in photography until he found Maier’s work. Inspired by her architectural photos, Maloof started taking his own pictures. “As I improved as a photographer and revisited her work, I realized that the cityscapes were not what mattered to her. It’s the people, the street scenes, and the overall composition,” he said. “There was so much more to this work than I thought, and I realized I was sitting on something more important than I ever imagined. Now our goal is to make her name known and to get Vivian Maier into the history books.”

When a novel is called ambitious, it often means it has not completely succeeded. However, this is not the case with Eleanor Catton’s book, The Luminaries. I interviewed her in the UK when her book was very popular, and she seemed calm, especially for someone in her twenties. She had just arrived from Germany and was flying back to New Zealand the next day. She shared a story about being stopped at passport control and asked to prove she was a writer. She pressed her novel against the glass. The official looked at it and asked, “What’s it about?” This is not an easy question for an author. 

The Luminaries takes place in New Zealand during the 1860s, where a series of crimes have happened, and a group of 12 men has come together to solve them. The story becomes very complex. Catton intended to write a murder mystery, not a historical novel, but she found that the past allowed for more complications and misunderstandings for her characters. The book is over 800 pages long because she wanted to give each of the 20 main characters a fair chance to shine.

When I asked her how it feels to be so successful at a young age, she responded thoughtfully. “It’s nice coming from a small country because everyone feels like the success is partly theirs. There’s a family-like feeling at home; I received a lot of support from other people’s grandmas.” She also mentioned that it bothers her when people think her book is not a serious project.

Catton explained that she wanted to write the book in a spiral shape, where each part is half the length of the one before it. The story speeds up as it goes along. I asked if it matters whether readers notice these patterns. She said she wanted to create a book with structural patterns that readers could notice if they wanted to, but that it wouldn’t matter if they didn’t.

Despite its unique structure, The Luminaries is still an exciting murder mystery with a captivating plot. Surprisingly, Catton said she did not know how the story would end when she started writing. “I would write myself into a corner and then see how creative I could be to get out of that situation.” One of her goals was to make the book enjoyable for readers.

We also discussed her love for television dramas, which often have cliff-hangers, different viewpoints, and dialogue. I asked if she would be interested in writing for TV. “That could be pretty cool,” she replied. She spoke with enthusiasm and laughed softly. She becomes animated when discussing her writing and New Zealand. “I notice that when I come to Britain, the landscape of my imagination changes just by being in a different place. I understand why writers leave New Zealand for more populated areas to be around more people.” For now, New Zealand will remain her home, and I hope it continues to inspire her for many more novels.

As a boy, Jonny Kinkead spent his time either making things in his dad’s garage or playing the guitar. For the last forty years, he has been building steel-string acoustic guitars by hand. He says, “I am still amazed by the guitar. How can two pieces of wood create such a beautiful sound? Different types of wood make different sounds, and that still surprises me.”

Jonny learned to play his brother’s guitar when he was eleven. At sixteen, he wanted to learn the bass guitar. Instead of getting a job to save money for one, he decided to make it himself. He studied how different shapes and types of wood affect sound and how to put them together. The bass guitar was the first instrument he built from scratch, but he had been making model boats and planes with his brothers for a long time. His father taught them how to use tools like saws and chisels. Jonny had also been fixing instruments for his friends.

Although Jonny’s bass guitar turned out well, he didn’t think about a career in guitar-making at that time. He was also interested in painting and sculpture. After finishing school, he chose to study architecture at university because it involved design. However, halfway through the course, he dropped out because he felt it didn’t suit him. He realized that guitar-building is a form of sculpture that creates sound, and he thought it might be a better career than pure art since people actually use the guitars.

Since then, Jonny has made guitars for a living. For the first ten years, he worked part-time cleaning windows to earn extra money. He sold his first guitars for just the cost of materials, but as he became known as a skilled guitar-maker, he could charge more. Even now, almost forty years later, he says he is “still scratching a living.” He can only make about ten guitars a year, which limits his income.

In the early years, Jonny focused on getting known. He attended music festivals most weekends to let musicians try his guitars and talk about him. He also had to learn how to price his instruments, which was difficult for him. Jonny believes it is easier for new guitar-makers in the UK today. When he started, many people thought only American-made acoustic guitars were good. However, UK-made guitars are now recognized for their quality.

Jonny thinks that new instrument-makers should take courses to learn valuable techniques. However, he also believes that learning through trial and error is important. He advises looking at other instruments to see what works and what doesn’t. He says, “If you make the back too thin or too thick, it won’t sound good. If you learn from someone else, you may only learn one way, but if you teach yourself, you learn everything.”

Text: 

When we talk about English conversation, we often start with the weather. This is a common tradition, and I will mention the famous saying by the 18th-century writer Dr. Johnson: "When two Englishmen meet, their first talk is of the weather." This saying is still true today, just as it was over two hundred years ago. However, many people stop here or try to explain why the English are so interested in the weather, but they often fail. They think that when we talk about the weather, we are really interested in it. 

For example, the American writer Bill Bryson says that English weather is not interesting at all. He points out that in England, we do not have extreme weather events like tornadoes or blizzards, which are common in other places. On the other hand, the English broadcaster Jeremy Paxman disagrees with Bryson. He believes that English weather is interesting because it is unpredictable. He says that while we may not have tropical storms, living near the ocean means we can never be sure what the weather will be like.

I believe that both Bryson and Paxman miss the main point. Our conversations about the weather are not really about the weather itself. Instead, talking about the weather is a way for English people to connect with each other. For example, when someone says, "Nice day, isn’t it?" or "Ooh, isn’t it cold?" they are not really asking about the weather. These phrases are just polite greetings or ways to start a conversation.

In fact, talking about the weather is similar to how monkeys groom each other. They spend time grooming, even when they are clean, to bond socially. There are specific situations where we use weather talk. Some people think that English people talk about the weather all the time, but that is not true. There are three main situations for weather talk: as a greeting, as a way to start a conversation, or as a topic to fill awkward silences. 

This is why it seems like English people talk about the weather a lot. A conversation might start with a weather greeting, then move to more weather talk, and return to it when there is a pause. This can lead others to think that we are obsessed with the weather.

Alice Leader was standing in front of Hadrian’s Wall in Britain, trying to explain to her class of 12- and 13-year-olds how amazing it was that the Romans built a wall that is 120 km long and 5 meters high about 1900 years ago. The students were interested in this trip, choosing it over more exciting tours to Spain, Greece, or France. However, they wanted to know why the wall was built, and Alice felt she did not have good answers. Unable to find a suitable historical novel to help her explain life at the Wall during Roman times, she decided to write one herself. After retiring from teaching for 31 years, Alice started her new career as an author in 2001. 

Alice felt that moving from teaching to writing was a big change. She said, “Teaching is like acting; it’s a performance every day and very demanding. Writing is exciting and a bit scary, but it’s not as tiring. My former colleagues envy me because I still connect with children through my stories.” Alice wants her novels to fill a gap in children’s fiction today. She believes that much of the young adult fiction focuses on negative experiences, which, while well-written, can be very dark. On the other hand, there is also a lot of fantasy, like Harry Potter. Alice’s books are different from both.

In her teaching, Alice always linked English and History, often teaching about ancient Greece alongside the novel "Tale of Troy." She loves the moment when a child goes from being bored to being interested and then from not understanding to understanding. “I enjoy having bored children because it challenges me to make them engaged,” she said. She sees her writing as a continuation of her teaching. 

Alice was inspired to write her first novel partly because she saw a gap in the market and partly because her two sons were leaving home, creating an ‘empty nest’ for her. Her head teacher suggested she take a creative writing course, which surprised her. “I had been teaching for 25 years, and I didn’t want to spend my summer on a course I thought I didn’t need.” Before she could join the course, she had to send in her best piece of fiction, which she only learned a few days before the course started. “I sat down at the computer and quickly created a story about a Roman couple and their baby-to-be.” After three hours and 30 pages, she submitted it and was accepted.

During the course, her classmates reviewed her work and encouraged her to publish it. With only 8,000 report cards as proof of her writing skills, she asked her head teacher for a year off to write her first novel. Alice’s husband, Zachary Leader, is a critic and editor, and his help was very important in editing her novel. Alice said, “My mother-in-law thinks we are rival authors, but I believe we work well together. He helps improve what I write – he reads a chapter and changes the sentence structure, and if something isn’t working, he suggests different words. My instinct is to keep adding more scenes. That’s the difference between a fiction writer and an editor.”

To raise money for charity, a newspaper and a TV company challenged brothers Jonny and Alistair Brownlee, who are champion triathletes, to take part in a special race. This race would have Jonny racing in a car on the roads, while Alistair would race on a mountain bike across the countryside. The race took place in the beautiful and hilly Yorkshire Dales in northern England. 

“I’m looking forward to it,” Jonny said at the start line. “I’ve never done anything like this before; it’s exciting! These roads have beautiful views, and it’s very cold, so I’ll be warm in the car.” Alistair, dressed in winter cycling gear, was also excited. “To be honest,” he said, “I’ve seen Jonny drive before, so I’m not sure he will make it. I might stop for a cup of tea halfway up.”

The race started at Semerwater lake in Wensleydale and would finish at Fleet Moss, Yorkshire’s highest road, which is about 350 meters high. This would be easy for the car, but Alistair had to climb a steep hill right from the beginning. After a quick handshake, they were off. Alistair quickly rode away on his bike, while Jonny got into his car and started driving. The big question was: who would reach the finish line first?

Jonny’s confidence was shaken when, just 15 seconds into his drive, he encountered a giant tractor blocking the road. “Welcome to Yorkshire,” he complained to the cameraman in his car. “If Alistair beats me, it’s all because of this farmer!” After getting past the tractor, Jonny continued driving, while Alistair struggled with the steep hill. He had to get off his bike and carry it up the hill, passing walls and fences. Sheep watched curiously as he kept moving forward.

Finally, Alistair reached the top of the hill. With the sun shining and open land ahead, he began to pick up speed. Meanwhile, Jonny faced another challenge. The narrow roads in the villages of Yorkshire were not made for fast driving. He had to slow down to get around a very tight corner and then drove through a stream that had formed on the road. Once he was clear of the last village, he raced straight towards the finish line.

Neither brother knew how close the other was. As Jonny sped through the final stretch to Fleet Moss, Alistair was racing across his last field and back onto the road. He pushed hard, and then suddenly had to brake as he reached the finish line. Looking around, he asked the crowd, “Is he here?” When they said no, he raised his arms in celebration and shouted, “Yes!”

A few moments later, Jonny arrived in his car and stepped out. “Well done,” he said, feeling disappointed. “I’m gutted.”

Text: "The silence is what you notice when you play on Centre Court at Wimbledon. You bounce the ball quietly on the soft grass; you toss it up to serve; you hit it and hear the echo of your own shot. The well-kept grass, the rich history, the old stadium, the players in white, and the respectful crowds all create a calm atmosphere that helps you focus. The quiet of Centre Court is good for my game. What I struggle with the most during a match is to block out everything except the game itself and the point I’m playing. The silence is broken by loud applause and cheers when a point ends. I hear the crowd, but it feels distant. I don’t think about the fifteen thousand people watching me closely or the millions watching around the world as I play Roger Federer in the 2008 Wimbledon final – the biggest match of my life. I had always dreamed of playing at Wimbledon. My uncle Toni, my coach, taught me from a young age that this was the most important tournament. By the time I was 14, I was sharing my dream with friends that I would play there one day and win. Before 2008, I had played and lost to Federer twice – in the final the year before and the year before that. The loss in 2006 was not too hard. I was just happy to have made it that far at twenty. Federer won easily, but my defeat in 2007 was much worse. I knew I could have played better; it was not my skill that failed me, but my mindset. I cried for half an hour in the dressing room after that loss. Losing always hurts, but it hurts more when you have a chance and lose it. Toni, who is usually tough on me, surprisingly told me there was no reason to cry and that there would be more chances at Wimbledon. I told him he didn’t understand; I felt this was my last chance to win. I know how short a professional athlete's career is, and I want to make the most of it. Every moment matters, but some moments are more important than others, and I had let a big one slip away in 2007. There was nothing Toni could do to make me feel better. But he was right in the end. Another chance came in 2008, just one year later. I was confident I had learned from my defeat; this time, my mindset would be strong. The best sign that I was ready was my belief that I would win. The night before the final, at dinner with family and friends, we didn’t talk about the match. I didn’t tell them to avoid the topic, but they understood that I was already focused on the match in my mind. From that moment until the match started, that focus was mine alone."

Text: In early April 1957, a young and idealistic Englishwoman arrived in Africa. In her first letter home, she wrote, "I am living in the Africa I have always longed for." Her name was Jane Goodall, and she would spend most of her life in Africa as a citizen, journalist, scientist, activist, and environmentalist. In 1963, the National Geographic Society in Britain helped make her famous by publishing articles and making documentaries about her research on chimpanzees. Her fame grew with her own writing, including popular children's books and the 1971 bestseller "In the Shadow of Man," which has been translated into 47 languages and is still available today. Jane Goodall is one of the most celebrated female scientists of the 20th century, second only to Marie Curie. However, her fame sometimes overshadows her real achievements. Many articles and interviews tell her life story, but they often focus on her personal life rather than her work. 

Despite this, Jane Goodall is recognized for her important contributions to science. She has greatly advanced our understanding of chimpanzees, showing that they have complex social and emotional lives. Before her research, people misunderstood the dangers of wild chimpanzees. No one knew that chimpanzees ate meat or used tools, and we did not realize that they share emotions similar to humans. Goodall's book, "The Chimpanzees of Gombe" (1986), is considered the most important work in chimpanzee research. Her long-term study of wild chimpanzees in Gombe State, Nigeria, is seen as one of the great scientific achievements of the Western world. Jane Goodall changed how we study animals and how we think about ourselves as humans.

Even as a child, there were signs of the scientist she would become. In the autumn of 1939, when she was just five years old, Jane disappeared one day. The police and her family searched for her. After a long search, she returned, covered in straw. When her mother asked where she had been, Jane explained that she wanted to know how hens lay eggs. To find out, she had hidden in a henhouse and waited for five hours until a hen laid an egg. This moment can be seen as the start of her journey as a biologist.

Text: 

In our first hour-long conversation, Shirley Ford talks to me using the voice of a playful 8-year-old boy, a tired mother, a funny elderly Scottish woman, and a very fast-talking alien. Her voices are familiar to viewers of children’s TV shows and cartoons, as well as people who have seen computer programs about health and safety. “I just did a voiceover about back injuries,” she says, “so I had to learn how to say many medical terms quickly.” 

Shirley explains what it takes to do voiceovers. “Many actors, even famous ones, think they can do funny voices, and many probably can,” she says. “But there is more to it. You need to bring the script to life for an audience that can’t see you. You wouldn’t believe how many well-known actors want to do voiceover work. Because of their fame, producers invite them to auditions, but often they don’t get the roles because they are used to acting with their whole bodies.”

After school, Shirley joined a drama course, hoping for a standard acting career. During the course, she occasionally worked singing jingles for TV ads. “One day,” she says, “the man who ran the recording studio suggested I try out for the voice of a rabbit in a cartoon. It seemed silly – I hadn’t studied drama to play rabbits – but I tried it for fun and, surprisingly, got a major role.” Shirley discovered she could do voices and that voiceover work might be her path. “Things just happened for me,” she says. “In my second film, I was lucky to play the main character – and her brother and mother.”

Adult female actors often provide the voices for small boys and girls because their voices are lighter than those of male actors. There are complicated procedures and many forms to fill out when hiring child performers, which production companies prefer to avoid. Shirley has learned to create different sounds and to avoid always sounding like the same child. She collects new voices by watching children’s TV. 

Cartoons are the best part of her job, which also includes educational videos and vacuum cleaner ads. “Those are tough because you have to sound excited about something you don’t care about, but my years in this job help,” she says. “I’ve learned that the trick is to smile while you talk – it makes your voice sound bright and cheerful. When I have days doing animation work, it feels like a holiday; working with other actors makes a big difference.”

The competition for work is strong, and a good showreel – a recording that shows what the artist can do – is very important. “It’s worth investing in a strong showreel,” Shirley says. “There are agencies that help voiceover artists create them.” She believes she has reached the top of her profession through hard work as much as talent. “Whether it’s making your showreel and taking it to film and TV companies, advertising agencies, and recording studios, or just practicing your voices, it’s all about setting goals and not giving up.”

For anyone thinking about a career in voiceovers, Shirley suggests attending “specialist workshops – they cover all types of voiceover.” She also thinks a love for human sound is essential, describing herself as obsessed with voices and becoming the characters she performs. “If I’ve been in the studio doing a specific American voice, for example, it can take over me, and I’ll speak like that for hours, maybe even days,” she says. “My children have grown up hearing their mom talk in completely different voices.”

Text: "People often ask me how I became a cartoonist. This is understandable because cartooning is a job many children dream about, like being a race car driver. However, most people eventually give up these dreams and choose more practical careers, like being a tax lawyer or making car parts. The idea that you can earn a living by drawing simple pictures, like those in high school notebooks, seems silly at first. Yet, some people do just that. 

Not everyone becomes a cartoonist in the same way, but most have wanted to do it for a long time. For me, I had a typical childhood for a cartoonist. I loved comic strips, contributed to school publications, and was known as ‘the kid who draws.’ I studied graphic design in college and, after graduating, I showed my illustrations to different companies. I was lucky to find a newspaper looking for political cartoons about local issues. I created a few ideas, and they bought them. In a few months, I was making enough money to support myself.

You don’t need much to become a cartoonist. You don’t need a university degree, a lot of money, or even to be a great artist. You just need your brain, your hand, and something to draw with. However, if it were that easy, there would be as many cartoonists as there are teachers. The barriers to becoming a cartoonist are low, but it is still a challenging job. You should only try to become a cartoonist if you feel you cannot do anything else. It is much easier to get a regular job that pays the bills and allows time for family, home repairs, and hobbies.

The more skills you have, the better chance you have of making a living with your art. I have created political cartoons, comic strips, and comic books. I have also worked as a writer, caricaturist, and designer. I don’t refuse any work because you can learn a lot from jobs you may not want to do. It helps to be intelligent, well-read, and curious about the world.

What about the business side of being a cartoonist? There was a time when many cartoonists could find regular jobs with different newspapers and magazines. But those days are fading. For most people today, cartooning is like running a small business. This means you not only have to create the work but also sell it. The more comfortable you are with this, the more successful you will be. 

I have seen cartoonists with average creativity and great business skills do much better than those who are very talented but lack other skills. It surprises me how often I meet people who have never sold a cartoon but are afraid someone will steal their ideas. Some are so worried that they won’t even let others see their work! Legally, to protect your work, you just need to draw a small ‘c’ for ‘copyright,’ circle it, and write your name and the date next to it. But honestly, it is more likely that no one will be interested in your work. If someone does steal a cartoon and it becomes popular online, it is not a disaster – it could actually be a lucky break!"

Text: 

Twenty years ago, I was moving to a new house and cleaning out my things. I decided to throw away an electric guitar that my dad had given me for my 16th birthday. It was a nice, black guitar made in Japan. I usually hate getting rid of old things, so why did I want to throw this one away? I took it to the dump and was about to leave it there when a young man came up to me, looking confused. “You’re not going to throw that away, are you?” he asked. I told him I was, and I started to feel regret. He asked if he could have it, and I said yes. After that day, I felt sad about my decision.

A few months ago, I received an email that changed everything. I remembered a story about a man who lost his wedding ring in the ocean and found it years later in a fish he was eating. That’s how I felt when I opened the email from a guitar dealer named Keith Rushton. He told me, “I’ve got your electric guitar.” It had been sold many times since the young man took it from me. Keith found my name on a label on the back of the guitar and used it to find me online. He contacted me through the newspaper I work for and offered to sell it back to me. I was so happy I could have cried. I would have paid anything for it, but his price was very fair. I had forgotten that my dad always put name labels on my things, including my guitar. I could imagine how my dad would have laughed at this strange situation!

My parents wanted me to learn classical guitar when I was young because it was popular in the 1970s. I loved the sound of it; it was calming and gentle. Unlike the violin, it didn’t sound bad when a beginner played it. But I struggled to improve, so I switched to the electric guitar, playing easier songs. This was also the time of punk music, when people who couldn’t play well could still be rock stars.

When I took my old guitar out of the box that Keith sent me, I remembered my birthday in 1978 when my parents gave it to me. Holding it again felt smooth and smaller than I remembered. I sat down to play, but then I wanted to stand up and put a strap over my shoulder because electric guitars are played that way. My fingers remembered where to go. I couldn’t draw the chords, but my hands just knew what to do. My fingers felt the familiar pain of pressing down the strings to play a chord. The electric guitar is not really meant for solo playing. Now that I’m learning it again, I think I should form a band. My son is learning the saxophone; maybe we can play together. Or maybe I can find other people my age who have had a similar experience. We could call ourselves “The Regainers!”

Text: 

Recently, there has been a lot of discussion about sleep. When I wrote the book *Insomniac*, which is about people who cannot sleep, I felt like I was one of the few warning others about the dangers of not getting enough sleep. Lack of sleep affects our minds, bodies, and moods. Many people who struggle with sleep understand how important it is. It is good that sleep is finally getting the attention it deserves. However, I wonder about dreams. There hasn’t been much talk about them. We often lose our dreams. When you wake up early because of an alarm, you miss out on the last hour or two of sleep, which is mostly REM (Rapid Eye Movement) sleep. This is the stage of sleep where we have the most vivid and emotional dreams. A good sleeper spends about a quarter of their sleep time in REM. If a person lives to be 90 years old, they will spend around six or seven years in REM sleep. When researchers prevent people from having REM sleep, they find that the next night, people experience more REM sleep to make up for it. This suggests that dreams are important.

In 1953, researchers discovered REM sleep, and many agreed with psychologist Sigmund Freud, who believed that understanding dreams was key to understanding our minds. However, later research showed that it was not that simple. The focus of dream studies changed from psychological reasons to physical ones. Currently, there is not much agreement among dream researchers, according to Harvard sleep scientist Robert Stickgold. 

Dreams are significant. At a meeting of the Associated Professional Sleep Society, P.F. Pagel from the University of Colorado Medical School shared a study showing that actors, writers, and directors remember and use their dreams better than others. He concluded that the use of dreams increases with a person's interest in creativity. It makes sense that filmmakers have a strong connection to their dreams, as film is very dream-like. However, I wonder if only creative people benefit from their dreams. Don’t teachers, software designers, and politicians also need to think creatively?

Stickgold explains that dreams help us connect ideas in new and surprising ways, using knowledge from the past and present to create new associations. Dreams may help us discover new patterns and combinations that break our usual ways of thinking. For example, Stickgold found that when people are woken from REM sleep and asked to respond to a word, their answers are more original than when they are woken from other sleep stages. They come up with unexpected ideas that make sense in a unique way. This is what creativity is, according to Stickgold. 

I find that I write better after having intense dreams. Even a difficult dream, or one I can barely remember, seems to help me think more clearly. On those days, my thoughts and ideas come out quickly, and I can hardly keep up with my typing. I don’t know exactly how it works, but it does seem to help. Creativity is not just for writers or artists. We live in a complex world, and everyone needs their brains to work well. We all need to think creatively and flexibly in our relationships with colleagues, family, and friends. This is why dreaming is important.

Text: 

Twenty years ago, Susie Ray left London to live in a small coastal town in south-west England. When you enter her studio, which has a beautiful view of the sea, you see many empty frames on the walls, along with smiling photos of her two daughters. As a leading artist in the copyist art movement, Susie can easily recreate the beauty of early 20th-century impressionist paintings and 16th-century Caravaggio portraits. However, she doesn’t keep any of her own work. “As soon as I finish them, they go,” she says with a shrug. 

Susie is in high demand. Over her 30 years as a copyist artist, she has painted many famous artists' works, including Renoir, Monet, and Van Gogh. Her reproductions are so accurate that art experts sometimes mistake them for the originals. While the original paintings can sell for millions of pounds, her copies sell for a few hundred pounds to £12,000, depending on how much time she spends on them. Susie does not reveal most of her clients, but they include galleries and private collectors. Some collectors are true art lovers, but for others, having a famous painting is about status. One celebrity likes to show off his “Van Gogh” painting, which is actually a “Susie Ray Van Gogh.” “Many famous people pass off my copies as originals,” she says. “That’s up to them.” Some collectors keep the original in a bank safe and display Susie’s copy to save on insurance.

Susie is honest about her work. When she copies an old masterpiece, she tries to make it look as real as possible because she believes it is important to respect the original artist. However, she always signs her name on the back of the canvas. Selling a copy as the real thing is illegal, and even though she knows people who have done this for money, she has never been tempted. Those who make fakes often get into trouble. Susie admits she isn’t rich and has faced challenges, but her situation is better now, and she doesn’t want to risk her reputation.

Before becoming a copyist, Susie worked as an illustrator for a botanical garden after earning her art degree. She worked for very little money for several years. Looking back, she sees that this experience helped her develop her skills and gave her a love for plants, even though it was hard to make a living. She had to be very precise and get things right the first time. She has no regrets about that time but is happy to have found a more financially rewarding career.

When younger artists ask Susie for advice, she emphasizes the importance of learning to draw accurately. She also highlights how much she has studied to reach her level of skill. Her training allows her to create everything from drawings of plants to perfect copies of 15th-century masterpieces and 20th-century abstract art, although she now focuses on French impressionists, with Manet, Cezanne, and Degas being her favorites. 

Susie mentions that many people think modern art is easy, almost like child’s play. However, she explains that impressionists painted quickly and freely, but they were also very careful and detailed, which makes it challenging to get right. Given her skills, it seems surprising that Susie doesn’t create her own original art. Isn’t art about self-expression? Could a Susie Ray original be worth more than a copy? She believes her work is the result of years of training and hard work, and she earns a good living from it. She has tried creating her own art, like oil paintings of fishing nets, but they ended up looking like photographs—fine, but not better than that. It’s like living on simple food after enjoying meals from a top chef. Susie is a perfectionist.

Text: 

During her racing days, Ellen MacArthur cared most about the sea and being the fastest on it. This passion started in her childhood. She had a special connection with the boats that took her around the world; they felt like one with her. When she returned to land, everyday life seemed unimportant. People would ask her about the race, but she quickly wanted to be back on the ocean, challenging nature, even in places that had almost defeated her.

After finishing second in the Vendée Globe, a solo round-the-world race, she showed me the small, stuffy cabin of her boat, Kingfisher. This was her home, workplace, and survival space for 94 days. She explained how she carefully planned everything, even counting the exact number of kitchen paper rolls she would need. Preparation was crucial for her. She proudly displayed her unappealing stock of freeze-dried food, a small gas stove, and bags of medical supplies. She took great care of her boat because her life depended on it.

Now, Ellen sees the world as a boat: a small, beautiful, and fragile thing with limited resources. A turning point for her was a trip to South Georgia, a remote island in the South Atlantic, where she helped with a bird survey on albatrosses. This experience made her reflect and see things differently. The many abandoned whaling stations served as a warning to her. She felt that humans often take what they want and move on without thinking.

When I arrived at Ellen’s office, she was finishing a busy conference call. She explained why we need to act now to save the planet. “Coal, oil, and gas are limited resources. We must find ways to use them wisely,” she said. Initially, her message was negative—telling people to use less—but she later found a more positive approach. Now, she talks about reusing materials, like industrial carpet tiles.

For the past three years, she has been visiting factories, mines, and power stations, discussing our dependence on non-renewable resources with government and business leaders. “I may not be an expert,” she said, “but I love learning. I couldn’t ignore the current situation. Compared to sailing, this feels more important. It’s about finding how my voice can help.”

Ellen also started the Ellen MacArthur Foundation, a charity that helps young people rethink and design a sustainable future through business and education. “I miss the adventure of being at sea,” she admitted. “It’s part of who I am. At sea, you feel connected to everything. You don’t have time to feel lonely; you focus on records, practical matters, and survival. My new message is more complex than just saying, ‘I want to be the fastest around the world.’ I may have been the fastest, but this work is more meaningful than anything I’ve done before.”

**Simplified Text:**

Jordan Romero is 13 years old and wants to be the youngest person to climb Mount Everest. If he succeeds, he could become very famous. He hopes to inspire other kids to go outside and explore, instead of just playing on computers and video games. Jordan's climbing team includes his father, Paul, and mother, Karen. They call themselves "Team Romero." Climbing Everest is just one part of their goal. If Jordan climbs Everest and Vinson Massif in Antarctica, he will be the youngest person to climb the Seven Summits, which are the highest mountains on each continent. Very few people do this before they turn thirty. Jordan has already climbed five of these mountains and might finish before he becomes a teenager.

I spoke to several experienced climbers who have climbed Everest, and none of them thought it was a good idea to take a 13-year-old up the mountain. They believe that while a young climber might be strong, they might not be emotionally ready. They also doubt that a young person has enough experience to make good decisions while climbing safely. The Romeros have heard these opinions before. Paul says, "I know there is criticism, but I can’t focus on it – we have a lot to do. I think about the risks, but I believe our experience as climbers will help. Watching Jordan grow gives me confidence. He is getting stronger and more mature."

I also wonder about Jordan’s reasons for wanting to climb. Is this just his father's dream? Paul says, "This project isn’t about me wanting to be famous through my son. At first, Jordan thought about doing this later in life, but we decided, ‘Why not do it now?’ We talk to him often to make sure he still wants to do it." When I ask Jordan what he enjoys about the challenge, he says, "I just focus on reaching my goal."

In the past, not many people cared about being the youngest or fastest to climb a mountain or sail an ocean. Now, every adventure is shared online, and every climb is seen as a chance to break records. The more exciting the record, the more people are interested. This creates a problem for Jordan. Some people think that focusing too much on achievements can take away the fun of the challenge. But if Jordan wants to inspire others, he needs to engage with the media. This means blogging, taking photos, and giving interviews. He needs to do something impressive, like climbing Everest. Paul adds, "If Jordan comes home tomorrow and says he wants to stop climbing and play basketball instead, we will end this project and go to the gym."
