When you see a teenager with an MP3 player, it’s likely they are not listening to classical music. Most people can name many pop groups, but if you ask my friends about Brahms, they usually don’t know who he is. I have just started a music degree, but my classmates know as little about classical music as most people our age. If you don’t know who created the music, you probably don’t own any of their recordings. This is sad for fans of classical music. Last year, only 3% of concert tickets sold were for classical music events, and the average classical recording sells only about 300 copies. I find this hard to believe. 

So, why is there less interest in classical music, which has been around for centuries? Older people often blame our love for TV and video games, but I don’t think that’s the reason. The truth is that classical music doesn’t attract most people, especially teenagers, who are the ones most likely to buy music and concert tickets. I know some teenagers who enjoy classical concerts, but they are few. Even though I play in an orchestra, I’m not a big fan of classical music. I like many styles, but my classical music listening is probably close to that 3% figure.

Why don’t teenagers like classical music? First, the pace and rhythm of classical music, with its many mood changes, can be hard for us. We prefer fast talking, fast playing, and fast thinking. Experts say we can only pay attention for about three minutes, which is too short for most classical pieces but just right for pop songs. Pop music is simple and easy to listen to, while understanding classical music takes time and focus. Also, pop music often talks about issues that matter to teenagers, while classical music does not.

The way we listen to music has changed too. In the past, families would play music together at home, and playing an instrument was important. Now, you can find any music online, but classical music is rarely part of our daily lives. When was the last time you heard classical music in a store? One of my teachers says that audiences at classical concerts have grown in recent years. Maybe, but I doubt many of those new audience members are teenagers. In my orchestra, we play classical music in many places, but when I look at the audience, I mostly see older people. 

I don’t know why more people enjoy classical concerts as they get older, but I do know that if your parents love something, you might want to avoid it. Some people say schools are to blame for teenagers’ lack of interest in classical music, but many kids are excited to play classical music in their school orchestras. They come early to practice and stay after school to rehearse. They enjoy classical music when they perform, but it’s not their favorite music otherwise. The two activities have become separate. When we want to relax, we always choose pop music.

Bonnie Wyndham got out of her mother’s car and looked at Almonside School. “I’ll make you sorry I’ve come here,” she said to the school, smiling. Her mother was getting out of the other side of the car and didn’t hear her, but Bonnie didn’t mind. Her mother already knew how she felt. Mrs. Wyndham looked around. Almonside was a strange school, with buildings hidden among the trees on a hillside; it looked confusing at first. Then she saw the signs: Science block, gymnasium, riding centre… “Riding centre,” Bonnie said, suddenly interested. “Headmaster’s study,” her mother replied. “This way.” Bonnie followed her mother along a wide path between the trees. “I wish you’d walk beside me instead of following me like a dog,” Mrs. Wyndham said tiredly, but she didn’t expect Bonnie to do that. 

A few minutes later, her mother was talking to Bonnie’s new headmaster in his study, while Bonnie waited outside the door. Suddenly, Bonnie stood up. “Why should I just sit here?” she thought. “I’ll be thrown out soon anyway, so why not get it over with?” She left the building and went to the riding centre, following the sign. There was a nice old building for the horses and a large area for indoor riding. Bonnie looked around, but there was no one there. She approached the horses with respect. They were well cared for, and she could see that right away. Almost every stall was occupied, and she walked along, looking closely at each horse. “I know what you’re doing here,” she said to a small pony, gently touching its nose. 

Then she saw the next horse and stopped. “But aren’t you the best of the lot!” she exclaimed. He was brown with a bit of white. He looked lively, which Bonnie liked. “I feel like we’ve met before,” she said, stroking his neck. “In my dreams, I was riding you to victory in a big competition…” The horse’s name was Maverick. Suddenly, she wanted to ride him. “I wonder where I can find a bridle and a saddle. It can’t be far.” She was happy to find that the room with the riding equipment was unlocked. 

As she put the saddle on Maverick, she forgot all about her mother and the headmaster. When she finally sat on the big horse outside, she felt like a queen, in control of everything she could see. Her nickname at her old school had been Queen Bee, and she laughed as she remembered it. “You’re the best horse I’ve ever ridden, Maverick,” she said with admiration. “I really mean it because I know about horses, even if I don’t know much else.” She nudged him to walk, then to trot. “If I stay here, I think you and I could be great friends,” she said. She rode around the paddock, feeling the rhythm of the movement and the breeze on her cheek. She could tell Maverick trusted her, and she felt sure he would jump well.

Text: "I have met Cody Simpson before and have always been impressed by his quiet confidence. The 15-year-old Australian has already released many successful songs. So how did a relaxed surfer end up on stage in front of thousands of fans? ‘I first picked up a guitar when I was six years old and started writing songs when I was seven,’ Cody says, remembering how it all began. ‘But I was swimming and surfing every day. Those activities were more important to me back then; I had a busy life. When I was 13 and in high school, I posted a few videos online.’ These videos changed everything. He started by posting a video of himself and a friend singing at a school concert. Fans commented online, asking for more videos. So Cody, who had recorded more at home, was happy to share them. The responses were amazing. 

Cody was also a talented swimmer. He trained hard with great coaches and focused on improving his sport. But then record labels contacted him, and he had a tough choice: stay in Australia and keep swimming, or take a big risk by signing a deal and moving with his family to the US. Cody decided to take the chance. ‘It was very hard for me – especially at such a young age – to choose a career. Can you imagine being 12 or 13 years old and trying to decide what you want to do for the rest of your life?’ He had to tell his swimming coach and friends that he was moving to the States. ‘It surprised most people. I’m kind of the quiet kid,’ he says, remembering their shocked faces. ‘I’m very modest, and I think it’s important to stay that way in this crazy world.’ 

So Cody packed his bags and moved with his family across the world, giving up one dream to try to make another come true. Although his family stays out of the spotlight and is not directly involved in his career, they support him from the background. Cody believes it’s important to have a close group of good people around you to stay grounded. Of course, everyone has doubts. ‘Sometimes when I’m alone, I think, “How does my decision affect my little brother and sister?” My little brother is eight years old, and he travels the world, doing school on the road; he doesn’t have a normal life,’ Cody admits. ‘I worry about how that affects him, but my family always reassures me that they support me in everything I do.’ 

Success in any career comes from being willing to say ‘yes’ to your big opportunity, even when it’s a little scary. ‘Everything happened so fast and unexpectedly,’ Cody says. ‘Now, I’m going to countries I never thought I’d visit and playing in front of hundreds of thousands of fans – it’s something many people dream of. But I know it won’t last forever.’"

Text: 

I jumped out of bed, pulled back a corner of the bedroom curtain, and looked down at the river bend. A new crack in the ice sparkled in the morning sun. I shaded my eyes and looked upstream at the sandbags, which were there to protect the buildings from flooding as the ice melted. My back still hurt from lifting them into place. Last week, I had worked with most of the town’s adults for long hours, showing that I could handle the job. My grandfather didn’t seem to notice much. 

With one hand on the curtain, I looked at the half-mile stretch of dark water created by the release pipe from the wood processing factory in Milltown. There were fragile ice shelves on both sides, and the dark water was followed by solid ice downstream. As I took off my pajamas and put on my kayaking wetsuit, I saw a boy on the other side of the river. I didn’t recognize him. I frowned. He was trying to balance on an ice shelf near the warm water from the factory. I zipped up my wetsuit and grabbed my kayaking jacket. I checked the pocket for my lucky chain – a silver chain my famous grandfather brought back from an expedition in South America. This chain is more special to me than having a famous grandfather, and only he, my mom, and I know about it. I also have the diary he kept during that trip, which I read before I sleep. I touched the chain again and went to the kitchen.

“Good morning, Rex,” my mom smiled as I took a banana from the counter. “You’re up early for a Saturday. I’ll make brunch after your training session. Be careful.” 

“Thanks, Mom.” I walked down the hallway and almost bumped into my tall grandfather as he came out of his bedroom. 

“Can’t you watch where you’re going?” he shouted. “Where are you going?” 

“Sorry, Grandpa. I’m going kayaking.” It was obvious from my wetsuit, and he had seen me in my kayak every morning. Grandpa can be difficult, and it’s been harder for me to ignore his temper lately. 

“What’s the point of training? You didn’t win the competition,” he said. His words hit me hard, but I took a deep breath and counted to three. He crossed the hall and slammed the bathroom door. My mom came in with a sympathetic smile. 

“Don’t mind him. He’s…” 

“...not himself right now,” I finished for her. I didn’t say that he had always been like this. But like my mom, I try to be understanding. When I was a child, he was my hero. He showed me photos of himself in National Geographic magazine. Those old photos still hang on his bedroom wall, along with his dusty medals and trophies. But I don’t go into his room anymore. I have my own collection of trophies to look at, and maybe one day, my own face in National Geographic. Still, a part of me wants to stay loyal to him, even though he is often grumpy. 

My mom smiled. “At least he’s coming out of his bedroom more. Have a good training session, Rex. I admire your determination to keep going, even on these cold days!” 

I smiled back as I peeled my banana. “It’ll be warmer in South America,” I said. “If I find sponsors for my expedition.” She laughed and went back to the kitchen. I finished my banana and went downstairs. Stepping into the backyard, I hurried towards the boathouse.

Text: 'Mum grabbed Jess by the arm. “Come with me,” she said. Jess followed her into the study. On the table, leaning against the wall, was an unframed painting. It was clearly one of Grandpa’s works, but it looked different from his usual style and was obviously unfinished. “Do you know anything about this?” Mum asked. Jess shook her head. “I’ve never seen it before. I didn’t know he was working on anything.” 

Jess looked closely at the painting. There was a river that took up most of the picture; it didn’t look like any river she knew, maybe it was just imaginary. The painting was strange and beautiful in a mysterious way. The riverbank was very small, with just a hint of green that was easy to miss, drawing the eye into the pale water and towards a hidden sea. There were no animals, birds, or people in the painting, and it felt right that way. It seemed like there was no place for living things in this distant scene. Still, she felt drawn to it, thinking about autumn coming after a long summer.

Mum spoke again. “It has a name.” There was something in her voice that showed her excitement, even though she tried to sound casual. Jess understood why. Grandpa never named his paintings. He just painted them and let others figure them out. Mum turned the painting over and pointed to the words Grandpa had written. Jess read them aloud: “River Boy.” The words felt strangely important to her, but she didn’t know why. 

Then she noticed something else. She looked at Mum. “There is no boy.” 

“Exactly. It’s strange, isn’t it? For him to be so specific. But maybe he will add the boy later since he hasn’t finished it yet. I made the mistake of asking him about it.” 

“Mum! You should have known better.” 

“I know, but I couldn’t help it. It’s such an unusual painting, especially with a name. You can guess what he said.” 

Jess didn’t need to guess. She knew Grandpa’s answer. “He told you it’s not the artist’s job to explain a painting because each picture has its own meaning, just like a poem, and we either understand it or we don’t. He said painting is hard work without having to explain it to everyone…” 

“Mum, he said ‘ignoramus.’” 

“… every ignoramus what it means. If artists had to explain their paintings to everyone who asked, they would never get any work done. And he said…” Mum interrupted her, laughing. “Something like that. Anyway, I was hoping you might know something about this painting since you seem to inspire him.” 

“Inspire?” 

“Someone who gives an artist ideas.” Jess knew what the word meant. Grandpa often used it when she watched him paint, but he usually said it to explain that the muse wasn’t helping him that day or that he needed to be nice to the muse because he had a hard part to work on. He never said the muse was about her. She always thought he meant some kind of goddess, not a real person. It was hard to imagine anyone, even a goddess, influencing someone as stubborn as Grandpa. “He doesn’t need me to inspire him,” she said. “He’s been painting all his life.”'

Text: 

This morning, I didn’t plan to cut a hole in my bedroom carpet. I’m not saying it was an accident, but it could have been. For example, if I had tripped over the bed with Dad’s Stanley knife in my hand, the blade might have gone into the carpet and made a big hole. I’m not saying that happened, just that it could have. I didn’t wake up thinking, “Today I will cut a hole in my carpet.” It just seemed like a good idea at the moment, as things often do. Later, I wonder why I thought that, but by then it’s too late. This happens to me quite often. 

What I was really doing was trying to fit my corner cabinet into a corner. Gran gave me the cabinet when she moved to a flat. It’s very cute! It’s small, painted white, with pink and blue flowers around the edge, and has tiny glass doors. Gran used to keep china ornaments in it, like shepherdesses and milkmaids. Now, I keep my collection of shells and fossils there. Gran knew I loved her corner cabinet, and I was excited when she gave it to me! 

The problem is, it is a corner cabinet, which means it has to fit in a corner. I only have two corners in my bedroom because it is the smallest room in the house, shaped like a wedge of cheese. The big front bedroom is for Mum and Dad, the back one is my sister Angela’s, the little one over the garage is my brother Tom’s, and my room is the size of a broom cupboard. Mum says when Angela goes to university, Tom can have her room, and I can have his. When Tom goes to university, I can choose any room. But since Angela is only fifteen, I think I will be stuck in my small room for a long time. 

I don’t really mind; I like my little bedroom. It’s cozy, like a nest. I love the sloping roof and the window at floor level. The only problem is the lack of corners! My bed is in one corner, and my wardrobe is in the other. I tried to fit Gran’s cabinet into the space between the roof and the floor, but it was just a little too tall. Then I thought, if I can’t cut anything off the cabinet, how about cutting a hole in the carpet? It seemed like the obvious solution. Dad calls this “lateral thinking.” I thought he would be pleased with me because he always tells us to “think outside the box.” And that’s exactly what I was doing!

The novel ‘The Borrowers’ tells the story of a family of tiny people who live secretly in the walls and floors of a house. They ‘borrow’ things from normal-sized people to survive. When I was asked to direct a TV version of the novel, I knew it would be difficult to meet people’s expectations. Fans of the book have strong ideas about how it should be. I used the original drawings from the book a lot because I wanted to avoid criticism from fans. The author wanted the series to show the story from the Borrowers' point of view, which made filming more complicated.

One of the most important things was getting the size right. The Borrowers are ten times smaller than humans, so when we filmed them walking across a room or going on a borrowing mission, we had to be ten times further away than usual. To show the Borrowers' perspective, the crew had to crawl on the ground and film from no higher than 15 centimeters. They went through many pairs of jeans! We only raised the cameras for aerial shots. A big challenge was getting the shadows right when we combined the tiny Borrowers with the normal-sized background. We created a special technique for this. After the series aired, famous director George Lucas called to ask how we did it.

The only permanent set we built was the Borrowers' home under the floorboards, filled with large objects to make the actors look small. It was very surreal. I remember asking them to carry giant scissors, and they really got into it. The coins were huge, bigger than dinner plates, and hard to lift. We often had to stop filming because the crew laughed so much. In the story, there is a scene where the Borrowers are swept down a drain. To film this, the actors had to go down a tunnel with hoses, and they said it was so scary that they didn’t need to act.

Getting the costumes right was very important to me, and other directors have struggled with this in past TV versions. I had the costumes made from heavy canvas so they looked like dolls' clothes. This made it hard for the lead actress to move. She couldn’t sit down during breaks and had to be sewn into her dress every morning. The lead actor's trousers were made from a rug because normal fabric would have looked too smooth. Unfortunately, it was very hot during filming, and I don’t think they appreciated my attention to detail with the costumes!

Most of the action away from the Borrowers’ home was filmed with the actors in front of a blue screen on an empty set. It was challenging for them to react to things that weren’t really there. I had to draw pictures of every scene to show how they should look – I made 2,000 drawings by the end. They weren’t perfect, but they worked. We didn’t have enough budget for special effects studios during the day, so I worked nights for three months. We had to work quickly – I once filmed a whole scene before realizing there was no film in the camera. But in the end, everything came together, and I think the series successfully captured the magic of the books.

Text: 

My mom stops the car at the corner of my new school, Palm Grove High School. She looks around nervously, expecting to see journalists, but there are none. I know that soon things will get crazy. There will be fake smiles, people pretending to be my friends, and requests for free concert tickets from my dad. “Everything will be fine,” I tell her. She kisses her fingertip and touches my cheek before I get out of the car. Then she drives away, leaving me alone in this new school and situation. But this is what I wanted. I wanted to leave my old life of touring and private tutors behind. While the rest of the band is here for recording, we are staying for good. I wanted to come to this school to meet real kids. I think it would be cool to meet someone whose mom works in an office or whose dad mows lawns. 

I walk into the school office. “Hi, I need my schedule, please,” I say to the secretary. “Name?” she asks, looking unfriendly. “Desert McGraw.” “Desirée?” she asks, leaning closer. “Desert,” I repeat. The secretary seems confused. “Oh,” she says and types my last name on her computer. That’s good because not many people recognize my last name since my dad uses a stage name. “What grade?” she asks. “Eleventh.” “One second, it’s printing,” she replies. Then she hands me my schedule. English Literature is my first class. Great! I like English. But I will be late because it’s in Room 214 on the second floor. I studied the map last night so I wouldn’t look lost. 

When I reach the door, I hear the teacher taking attendance. “Aurelio Gonzalez.” “Here.” I slip in quietly and sit at the back of the class. The girl next to me smiles and looks at my normal outfit – jeans and a T-shirt. “Nice shoes,” she whispers. I look down at my expensive shoes with flowers on them. Oh no, I shouldn’t have worn these. “Thanks,” I say. The teacher pauses and calls my name. “Desert... McGraw?” she says. “Here.” The teacher smiles and introduces herself as Ms. Smigla. She talks a lot and gives us our course outlines. After explaining the books we will read this year, she lets us socialize! 

“So why did you move here?” my new friend asks. I have a few options. Should I say I wanted a normal life away from cameras and reporters? Or should I tell the real reason my dad gave? “We need a change, Desert,” he said, “and this is the perfect place to record the new album. It has energy, color, and culture.” Personally, I think he just wants to relax on the beach. Why else would they choose South Beach Sounds, a studio right by the sand? “My dad had to relocate,” I tell her. Yes, it’s easier to lie. “What does he do?” she asks. I know everyone will find out eventually, but I want to pretend to be normal for a while. “He’s an artist,” I say, playing with my backpack zipper. “Cool. I’m Becca, by the way.” She doesn’t seem to care much. That’s great.

Text: 

Today, American teenage girls are expected to do a lot. They should be the president of the Student Council, have a part-time job, volunteer, and do well in school. Being an average teenager is not enough anymore. Many people think that if teenagers do not have big ambitions, they are being lazy. 

Kristen Loose, a teenager, says that adults often forget how much pressure teenagers face. They have a lot of homework, tests, after-school activities, jobs, chores, and responsibilities at home, all while trying to have a social life. Even with these challenges, negative stereotypes about teenagers still exist. Some people in the media describe teenagers as lazy, disrespectful, rebellious, loud, reckless, and self-centered. While some of these traits may be true for a few, many believe it is unfair to label all teenagers this way.

Kristen Loose thinks that many people wrongly assume teenagers spend all their time on their phones and watching TV. She admits to having her phone nearby most of the time, but she uses it for important things, not just for fun. For teenagers today, phones are tools that help them manage their lives. They need to be reachable and have access to information at all times, which can make it seem like they are addicted to their phones. With smartphones, tablets, and social media, students can do their homework anywhere, and schoolwork never really stops. 

Many teenagers wake up around 6 a.m. or 7 a.m. and often stay up past midnight. Their days are filled with school, activities, family duties, and homework, leaving them with little time to sleep. The US National Sleep Foundation found that only about 20 percent of American teenagers get the recommended nine hours of sleep each night. Additionally, 28 percent of teens said they fall asleep in school about once a week because they are too tired.

Teenager Lindamarie Olsen believes that after all her activities, she has about 18 hours of free time each week. With 168 hours in a week, this is not a lot. She does not spend much of this time on social media or TV; instead, she focuses on volunteering. Lindamarie thinks that many people believe teenagers only care about themselves, but she enjoys helping others. She looks forward to making a positive impact in her school and community.

In the future, the stereotypes about teenagers may change, but they will continue to challenge these ideas and make a difference in the world. There will always be new generations of students who are ready to take on the world before they even finish school.

The teenage members of the Earth to Sky Calculus Club live in and around Bishop, a mountain town in the US, surrounded by wilderness east of the Sierra Nevada mountains. In recent years, this small group has launched over fifty balloons to the edge of space, about 35 km above the Earth. This is a long-term science project that combines astronomy and adventure, which is likely why teenagers want to join. I joined them one weekend in late spring as they prepared to release a high-altitude balloon to record shooting stars. Shooting stars happen when a rock or piece of metal from space enters the Earth's atmosphere and creates a bright trail of light.

As it got dark, the teenagers attached a soft insulated $5 lunch box to the bottom of the balloon. Inside the lunch box were a camera, an instrument to measure altitude, and a thermometer to check temperature changes as the balloon rose. Two GPS trackers were placed on the outside of the lunch box to help the group find it later. They used a gas tank, donated by a supporter from another state, to inflate the balloon, which grew to the size of a small car. An older boy made a seven-hour trip to get the gas tank. “I didn’t really mind,” he said. For kids in this club, that’s normal.

Finally, it was time for lift-off. “Five, four, three, two, one,” they counted down, and the balloon began to rise. Some of them ran and followed its path with powerful flashlights until they could no longer see it in the dark sky. There was a quiet moment filled with wonder as the balloon disappeared into the night. After the launch, most students went home, but a few stayed to watch the shooting stars. They lay on blankets on the mountainside, looking at a sky so clear that it was hard to believe they were only four hours from Los Angeles, a busy city with around 4 million people. I saw a boy climb into a sleeping bag and quickly fall asleep. “We’re the only ones talking,” said one girl quietly. “I know,” whispered another. Suddenly, a meteor shot across the sky.

As the balloon rose, the air pressure decreased, causing the balloon to expand until it was almost the size of a house. Then it popped with a loud bang. A parachute helped the lunch box land safely back on Earth. The students would find it the next day using the GPS trackers. Finding it was not easy, but that was part of the fun. There is little inhabited land around Bishop, so the lunch box usually lands in a remote area. “Recoveries are a big part of the program,” said the group’s leader, noting they had only lost two lunch boxes in 53 launches. “Part of the journey is getting to know this landscape in a way you normally wouldn’t.”

On this occasion, the lunch box landed 84 km west of Bishop, but to reach it, the recovery team had to drive south of the Sierra and then back up the western side of the mountains. They had to decide whether to drive or walk, as it could be dangerous if the lunch box was on a high peak or in a tall tree. “These students are familiar with the Eastern Sierra,” their leader said. “What seems wild and dangerous to some is just a normal part of life for others.” In the end, it took them 11 hours to find the lunch box. It was in a canyon, on a flat rock, near a waterfall. The camera did not capture any shooting stars. While this was a bit disappointing, it also gave them a chance to discuss atmospheric waves and how they work above mountains. It was just one more adventure to share with anyone who asked.

Chloe Morgan admits that she was not very interested in science, especially Palaeontology, until she was fifteen. Her interest began by chance when her younger brother was excited about dinosaurs, a phase many children go through. Although she initially dismissed it, she helped him with a science project and found an article about recent discoveries in Palaeontology that amazed her. She realized she wanted to pursue this field.

Chloe recalls meeting her first professional palaeontologist, Matt Cornelius, who was already well-known despite being young. She felt nervous at first, worried he might think she was just an annoying kid. However, she felt more comfortable when he showed patience and listened to her questions.

When discussing how palaeontologists are shown in movies and TV shows, Chloe expresses her frustration. She believes films like Jurassic Park have increased public interest in dinosaurs but often misrepresent palaeontologists. They are usually portrayed as either eccentric geniuses or socially awkward people, which does not reflect the reality of their work.

Chloe explains that her job is very varied. She spends time digging up dinosaur bones, working in laboratories to analyze fossils, and writing scientific papers. Although it is not her main job, she also believes it is important to communicate scientific findings to the public, especially young people. She wants to inspire children to learn about science, using dinosaurs as a way to spark their interest in the natural world.

Chloe was involved in the TV documentary Walking with Dinosaurs, where she provided advice to ensure the dinosaurs were accurately portrayed. She found it easy to help because there were not many mistakes to correct. The documentary attracted viewers of all ages, showing that our understanding of dinosaurs has improved significantly compared to older films like Jurassic Park.

Chloe believes dinosaurs continue to fascinate us because they represent the explorer in all of us. They capture our imagination and remind us that there is still much to discover in the world. She sees Palaeontology as a way to travel back in time.

Text: "I want to say this clearly: when you are traveling by car with your family, even if you are six years old, you know that you are not ‘there yet,’ even if you keep asking, ‘Are we there yet?’ The truth is, once you arrive, it’s not ‘there’ anymore; it’s ‘here.’ So if you think you might be ‘there’ already, you should be asking, ‘Are we here yet?’ I’m sure no one wants to be ‘there yet’ more than the parents who hear that question over and over on long car trips. 

Think about it. Wouldn’t you rather relax in the back seat, with no responsibilities? You could watch DVDs, listen to music, or do puzzles while enjoying the beautiful views outside the window. In the front seat, there’s a parent with juice boxes and cookies, adjusting the radio and temperature to keep everything running smoothly. 

But then, someone in the car does something annoying—usually my younger brother, Tim. He might put his foot on my side of the seat. I can’t let that happen, so I put my foot on his side. Soon, he’s all over my space, and a fight starts. The driver and the other parent have to reach back to separate us while the car swerves. They tell Tim to stay in his own seat and keep his hands to himself. This calms things down for a bit, and we can enjoy the beautiful scenery again.

Later, when I’m trying to read, I feel a draft on my arm. The window isn’t open, so where is it coming from? Tim is next to me, quietly blowing his breath in my direction. He’s not touching me, so he thinks he’s being clever. This makes me angry. Tim gets yelled at again, and the car swerves more. Eventually, things calm down again.

Over the years, Dad has come up with ways to handle us in the back seat. When we ask, ‘Are we there yet?’ he often says, ‘Yes, we’re here. Get out of the car.’ But we are still on the highway, going fast. Then he says, ‘Oh, maybe we’re not there yet.’ This keeps us quiet for a while. 

You can tell when you finally arrive because the adults jump out of the car and move as far away from the kids as possible. So remember: if your parents are still close enough to answer your question, then the answer is: no, you’re not there yet."

John and Zuzi Morgan have opened a café in Oxford, UK, where people can enjoy coffee, cake, and play board games. They hope that customers will love the experience and want to come back. Zuzi explains their motivation: “There is so much technology today. Everyone is busy with their phones and gadgets. We wanted to bring people together in a way that doesn’t involve screens. It’s natural for people to connect and communicate.”

The games played in their café are called ‘Eurogames’. These games often have gentle themes, like farming and building landscapes. The first Eurogame was The Settlers of Catan, created by German designer Klaus Teuber. In this game, players build settlements on an island and trade resources, keeping everyone engaged until the end. This idea was improved in ‘co-operative’ games, where all players work together to win or lose as a team, which encourages more social interaction. One popular co-operative game is Pandemic, designed by North American Matt Leacock. In Pandemic, players work together to solve global problems. Leacock was inspired by a Eurogame called Lord of the Rings, which is based on the famous book. He remembers, “When I played that with friends, we felt scared and excited. In the end, everyone felt good, whether they won or lost. I wanted to create something like that.”

Leacock’s love for board games started when he was a child. He enjoyed receiving games as birthday gifts but often felt disappointed when they didn’t meet his expectations. With help from his uncle, he began to redesign games to make them better. Pandemic became very successful, and its follow-up version improved game design even more. Leacock explains, “It has a lot of storytelling. It’s like a video game where you develop characters, get new rules, and the story changes.”

Interestingly, the growth of the video game industry has helped the success of modern board games. Many people now play games on their smartphones, making them more open to playing board games. Ben Hogg, who works for a game company, says, “Everyone plays mobile games now. Most people with smartphones have at least one game they enjoy.”

For a while, video games allowed some social interaction, like playing together at arcades or on the couch. However, as multiplayer games moved online, players became more distant from each other. This led some people to seek out ways to play games with others in person again. In John and Zuzi's busy café, it is clear that tabletop gaming has become more than just entertainment. In our online world, games are now something to be shared directly and physically, and this trend is likely to continue.

Jamie Scott has written and produced some of the biggest hits in the UK in recent years. His story shows that endurance and persistence are very important in the music business, even if your career starts with many failures. He says his mother was an amazing singer who helped him learn to play the guitar. The only radio station he listened to at home was for middle-aged people, which influenced his music taste as he grew up. He was 12 years old when he first heard a modern song. Around the same time, he had to choose between playing tennis, which he played at a national level, and music. He spent his lunchtimes in the music room at school learning songs on the piano. He said, “I was doing well in tennis, but it was not what I wanted to do for my whole life. It was just too much hard work.”

At 17, he left school to become a performer. He formed a duo with a friend who was a good guitarist but did not want to pursue a music career. Jamie remembers going to his parents and telling them he wanted to be a musician. He had been writing lyrics during economics lessons and playing the piano every day while others were outside playing. His father gave him 18 months to succeed; if he didn’t, he would have to find a job. After some close calls with record labels, he was signed to a music publisher at 19 because of one song. However, record labels wanted him to be a solo artist, so he had to part ways with his friend.

Eventually, he became more successful as a songwriter than as a performer. After a tough time with a record label in the UK, he asked to leave and joined another label to release a new album. However, he did not become famous right away. He said, “I feel like I’ve been in the wrong place at the wrong time for most of my artist career, but as a writer, I’ve been in the right place at the right time.” Writing for other artists is where he found success. He believes he is one of the main writers in the UK that labels turn to for new artists. He helps launch their careers.

Sometimes, he has to explain to the artists he works with that wanting to write popular songs is not something to be ashamed of. He asks them, “Don’t you want 10 million people streaming your music next month?” He believes they should aim to create songs that are both amazing and likely to sell well. It is refreshing to hear someone in pop music speak openly about wanting to write big hits. Jamie is not arrogant; he knows he has a talent for writing number one songs. Instead of trying to please others, he focuses on his goal. He says, “When I go into the studio with someone, we need to aim for the best music of next year. It’s not just about what’s cool; we want to write classic modern pop songs.”
