Tony Connor is a new kind of celebrity. He is very popular online, but many people, like me, may not know him if they don’t watch videos of people doing tricks on bikes. He is known as a ‘street trials cyclist.’ This means he jumps from difficult places, like roofs or walls, to land safely in other tricky spots. These stunts are recorded and shared online.

On the day I interview him, we meet at a BMX park on a Saturday morning. The local kids all know who he is, and some older people come to greet him, calling him ‘an absolute legend.’ After watching him perform, I agree with them. At first, I was a bit doubtful, but I am impressed by his bravery, creativity, and willingness to take risks. Before each stunt, he explains what he plans to do, and sometimes I can’t believe he will succeed. When I compliment him after his stunts, he seems uninterested and a bit sad. Even though he is famous online, Tony says he does not enjoy being a celebrity. He finds it hard to connect with fans. He understands the importance of talking to them, but he prefers to focus on doing his stunts.

This is interesting because his fame comes from social media and the small cameras that help create this content. He says, “This technology allows people like me to earn money.” Sometimes he feels that everyone is filming themselves or looking at screens, and he doesn’t fully agree with that. However, he is not complaining. Through his videos, he makes a good living from what used to be just a hobby for others.

After many years of interviewing top athletes, I have learned that two important things help a child become a great competitor: energy and the ability to handle disappointment. These qualities can be more important than talent and help someone keep going even after failures. In risky sports, it is especially important to have mental strength. Even in the park, Tony fell a few times on what he thought were easy but new challenges. He just got back up and kept trying until he succeeded.

Not everyone sees Tony as a hero. Some people think he is reckless and takes too many risks. He responds, “Those who criticize me may care, but they don’t understand. They probably have never ridden a trials bike and don’t know much about the sport. They don’t realize that I get advice from experts to reduce risks.” In reality, Tony is careful about the risks he takes. He explains, “People are different. Some never feel scared, and they shouldn’t be doing these sports. It’s important to know the dangers. The rest of us can be divided into two groups: those who can’t overcome fear and those who can. I belong to the group that feels fear but finds a way to move past it. I’m not addicted to risk; I spend a lot of time planning and preparing. Sometimes I ride around for a while to get ready before trying a new stunt. I know I must stay calm just before I jump. If I fully commit, then I’m okay.”

Television presenter Helen Skelton has taken on many dangerous challenges for charity, such as running a marathon in the desert and traveling down the Amazon River in a small boat. For her latest challenge, Helen walked on a high wire, which is a long, thin piece of metal, 66 meters above the ground, between two towers of an empty power station. There was no safety net; she only had a belt around her waist that was attached to another wire above her. To help her balance and avoid falling, she carried a long stick that weighed eight kilograms. 

Helen trained with an expert high-wire walker. Even though she had some circus skills, she found that high-wire walking was very different. “The training was a shock,” Helen said. “I didn’t realize how strong I needed to be. Every day started at 8 am with a run up a steep hill, followed by an hour of exercises, and then another hour practicing on the wire. I also had to learn how to fall onto the wire so I could keep going if I slipped. Every time I fell, it hurt a lot. But I had to stay positive: if I got nervous and started shaking, the wire would shake too!”

On the day of the challenge, it was windy, and Helen calmed herself by taking deep breaths as she moved step by step along the wire. The 150-meter walk took her 15 minutes. “That was the scariest thing I’ve done,” she said afterwards. “I’m glad it’s over!” Despite this experience, Helen is already planning her next charity project: to reach the South Pole by skiing, kiting, and biking.

In 2006, Jeff Somers started a journey around the world on a penny farthing, an old-style bicycle with one large wheel and one small wheel. He had already written a book about his travels in Canada using a 50-year-old car. Jeff loved motorsport and worked building racing car engines. To save money, he rode an old bicycle to work and also used it for a holiday in Amsterdam. He says, “That trip opened my eyes. I decided to see the world by bike.” Jeff wanted a unique touring bike and decided to build one himself. He thought the most interesting bike would be a penny farthing, so he visited a museum to learn how they were made.

After two attempts in 2001 and 2003, when he had to stop because of a knee injury, he finally began his journey in 2006. He traveled for three years, visiting 23 countries on four continents. The highlight of his trip was reaching Tibet and seeing Mount Everest. He met other cyclists who could ride up mountains, but he never regretted using his penny farthing. The further he traveled from home, the more amazed people were by his bike.

His worst experience was when he had to drink dirty water from a stream, which made him very sick. He spent ten days in a hostel without medicine and had no money for a hospital or to return home. Despite these challenges, Jeff now says, “If I could afford it, I would start traveling again tomorrow on my penny farthing.”

I work at a university in the US, where my team and I are studying water birds, especially the American black duck. We have just started using a new tool called a ‘night-vision scope’ that helps us see the ducks in the dark! We are concerned about black ducks because their numbers have decreased a lot, and we are unsure if there is enough food for them on the east coast. We know a lot about what they do during the day, but we don’t have information about their nighttime activities because we didn’t have the right equipment. This new scope will give us clear images, even on nights without a moon, so we can learn more and make better decisions about protecting their habitat.

Our work is challenging. There are four of us, and we each work six hours a day. We have studied ducks in different places, and I have had to take a boat to some locations and write down notes on every duck I see. The weather has been difficult – some nights are warm, but most of the time it is rainy. It is also very quiet, so I have needed a lot of coffee to stay awake! We have only missed one workday because the snow was too deep for our special vehicles. I enjoy this challenge, especially when I think about the summer, when we will spend hours in a laboratory analyzing our results together. It will be hard to be indoors, but it is necessary. I wouldn’t change this experience for anything!

Text: "When I tell people what my job is, they often can't believe it exists. But I’m serious! I spend my days at work tasting chocolate! Tasting chocolate is very important to make sure that customers receive high-quality chocolate from my company. Every week, I get samples, which are small amounts of chocolate, from our factory. I need to check them for taste, texture, and smell. I also taste the raw materials we use, like nuts and fruit, to choose the best ones for the chocolate. 

Next to my office, I have a kitchen where I can test and taste the products I create, and I share samples with my colleagues! My kitchen is filled with machines and ingredients to experiment with. It’s great to have a private space to go to during the day. No two days are the same in this job. Sometimes I work in our food lab, and other times I travel to buy raw materials, which can be hard because I have a young family. However, I enjoy the variety and lack of routine in my job, although I still love the chocolate the most!

People often ask me if I get bored of chocolate. I’ve worked with it for a long time, and I’ve never felt tired of eating it. In fact, I often go home and eat more chocolate in the evening!"

Text: "Have you ever thought about what it’s like to perform in a circus? Sophia Grayson works at Circus Experience, a center that teaches young people circus skills. She says her course is popular because it includes many skills, such as juggling, throwing and catching balls, and even fire. It also teaches trapeze, where performers fly through the air in front of an amazed audience. 

In the year-long course, students gradually take more risks in each class, and parents can come to some classes to see their progress. Sophia explains, “For a career in the circus, performers need to avoid doing the same thing all the time. It’s important to keep performances exciting and full of action. If you want to be successful in the circus, you must keep practicing. Another great part of this job is making friends with other performers and learning from them. Staying fit is also very important. Circus artists, like athletes, train every day to stay strong. Training is essential, but the best performers are those who want to succeed, have creativity, and always work on improving their skills. 

People often think that circus performers are likely to get injured or that they only work for a short time each year. However, the real challenge is planning for the future because you can only travel while you’re young, and then you need to think about other options.” The course also teaches business planning. Many former students have started their own businesses around the world and are happy to share their experiences. Sophia warns, though, that it’s not a job for making a lot of money! “The work usually does not provide a regular salary. It’s also competitive, but it’s a lot of fun!”

Text: "You may not know her name or face, but you have probably heard her many times. Mariam Hobson is a professional backing singer. This means she sings in the background to support the main singer. Many people think backing singers are not good enough to be lead singers, but that is not true – they often have to be even better. People like Mariam are the real stars of the music industry!

Mariam says, 'What I love about my job is that when I go into the recording studio, I never know what I will be asked to sing. It could be classical, jazz, hip-hop, or rock. Sometimes, it might even be a funny song for a radio station or an advertisement. I am often surprised by what producers ask for. Once, I was asked to sing like a fish underwater! But I never complain; I just do my job!'

'To do my work well, I need excellent musical skills and the ability to learn quickly. There is often no written music to follow. I will never forget my first time recording background music for a film. It was very complicated because there were eight of us, each singing a different part, along with an orchestra. I was very nervous because if I made a mistake, we would have to record everything again, which nobody likes. Recording sessions are already long enough!'

'One of my favorite jobs is recording for songwriters. Less experienced writers sometimes do not know which musical range is best for a female voice. By listening to me sing their song, they can figure out how to improve it.'"

Text: 'Julie Deane started with only basic knowledge of fashion, but she built a successful business selling ‘satchels’ – traditional bags used by schoolchildren. These satchels are now sold in famous shops and are popular with many celebrities. Before deciding to sell satchels, Julie considered different business ideas, like cake decorating and party planning. She wanted to make the right choice. When she chose satchels, not everyone agreed with her. Julie recalls, “Many said there was no demand for them – but I was convinced.” She involved her family from the beginning, working with her mother, who had never worked before but had a natural talent for business. The design of the satchels was inspired by children’s storybooks. 

Although Julie didn’t know much about fashion blogs, they became important for her success. At first, she sold about one satchel a week. To create interest, Julie sent satchels to fashion writers, hoping they would write about them in their blogs. They did, and interest in her satchels grew, along with the speed at which her company produced them. Now, Julie enjoys waiting to see which celebrity will be seen with a satchel! While other companies spend money on online ads, she uses the internet community for ideas on new styles, keeping her products fresh and exciting. 

There was a difficult time when another company copied Julie’s design to sell similar bags. Because of this, she now makes sure she trusts her production team as much as her own staff. Visitors often comment on the positive atmosphere in her offices – people enjoy working there. There is now a new factory, and while the buildings are important, it is the team that makes it a special place.'

When Vicky Harmiston was a child, her parents allowed her and her brother Jamie to choose how they spent their free time. Vicky enjoyed many different sports. She was a good swimmer, and her coach at the swimming club believed she could become a champion. However, the club was far from her home, making it hard for her to balance training with her schoolwork. 

As teenagers, Jamie, who loved cycling, bought a special racing bike and started competing. Vicky thought this looked exciting and decided to try cycling too. She later said it was the best choice she ever made. Soon, she was cycling every day and doing very well. The track was close to her school, so it was easy for her to attend training sessions after school. Vicky had a successful career in track cycling and won several competitions. When she turned 28, she retired from competitive cycling. Vicky explained, “For years, I loved winning, but I started to feel tired of it all. When the excitement goes away, there’s no reason to continue. Fortunately, I found a new career.”

Vicky got a job with a charity called CycleZone. “We work with young people who have never enjoyed sports,” she said. “The first thing we do is teach them to ride a bike. We want them to believe in themselves and their abilities. CycleZone does a great job of bringing young people together so they can be part of a larger group.” The charity uses celebrities to promote their work. Vicky mentioned, “Some people think celebrity support is not always good for a charity. They believe celebrities do it for their own benefit, which can distract from the charity's real work. But if famous singers and actors can help, I think they should.”

Singer-songwriter Ana Ronson grew up in Ireland. Even though her parents were not musicians, there was always music in their home. Her grandfather played the guitar and taught Ana and her brother how to play. The first time Ana sang in front of an audience was at school, and she was so nervous that her teacher had to take her off the stage. This teacher suggested that Ana join the school theatre club to help her gain confidence. After being in the club for a while, she happily sang with 50 other students at a concert at the end of the term.

A year later, her brother, who was in a band, asked her to write a song for them. She wrote her first song, "Falling Stars," in just three days and enjoyed it so much that she signed up for a songwriting course with a professional songwriter. Even though she was the youngest student, she knew more about music than many of the others. However, Ana felt that the teacher did not listen to her, so she wrote a song called "Something to Say" about her frustration. She shared this song online, and it became very popular. She was thrilled when people commented that they loved it and found new meanings in the lyrics each time they listened.

Joss Alton, the owner of a recording company called Isotope Music, traveled from the other side of Ireland to invite her to join the company. At first, Ana was unsure because she did not know much about Isotope and did not want anyone telling her what to sing. However, Joss convinced her that this would not happen. Soon after, she performed at a concert in Dublin organized by Isotope. The tickets sold out quickly, and it was a fantastic evening.

Ana prefers to write songs about difficult times rather than happy moments because she feels she has more to express. One of her favorite songs is "Decision," which is about why her brother stopped singing for a while and how unhappy it made him. While she hopes her fans will enjoy her music, her goal is to write about personal experiences that are important to her.

Last year, I went on an incredible trip – a guided boat tour along the west coast of Canada. It was my brother Harry’s idea. He is a journalist, like me, and wanted to write articles about the trip. He loves boats, but I don’t share that interest. However, I had always wanted to visit this area since I saw it on TV as a child, especially because it was where our great-grandparents lived before moving to Europe. I kept asking Harry if I could join him until he finally said yes!

A few days before we left, there were storms in the area we were going to. Luckily, the weather forecast for our trip was good, with calm seas. I was busy with work and didn’t have much time to prepare, but Harry promised he would take care of everything, so I stopped worrying.

After we arrived in Canada, we met the group, packed our supplies into small boats, and set off. The guide told us that very few people live along that coast, and on our first morning, the only other creatures we saw were dolphins and birds. We could see islands in the distance, but the morning fog made it hard to see far, so I focused on the beautiful patterns our boat made in the water.

We often stopped for hours to explore the rock pools on the beaches. They were full of colorful fish, many of which I didn’t know. It was nice to forget about time and just enjoy the moment. We always remembered to have lunch and dinner, which we cooked together over campfires. At night, when we fell asleep on the boats, even though the beds were hard, it felt like a stress-free life!

When it was time to leave, I felt sad. How could I go back to normal life? But I knew I would miss my family and friends. I was also excited to share our adventures with everyone at home!

Text: "My dad was a professional basketball player in Germany, just like his father before him. When I was a kid, I went to many of his games. You might think that watching so many matches would make me love basketball, but it did the opposite. I enjoyed telling my friends how good my dad was, especially when he won, but I often took a book to read instead of watching the games.

When I started secondary school, I was already two meters tall, even though I was not yet a teenager. My sports teacher noticed my height and asked if I wanted to train with the basketball team. I liked the training, but I thought I needed to improve my skills before playing in a real match. The teacher believed in me more than I believed in myself. After some time, I agreed to play, and a few weeks later, I found myself in a game against another school. My parents watching made me more nervous, but it turned out fine!

For the next four years, I practiced every day and did very well. I even joined an adult team before moving to a special sports academy in the USA when I was fifteen. The coach there trained Olympic basketball players, and it was amazing to work with him. However, I didn’t enjoy living far from my parents at first. At home, I hadn’t spent much time with friends because of all the training, so that part wasn’t too different for me. Eventually, I got used to my new life, and my English improved quickly too!

I became a professional player at eighteen, three years after arriving in the USA. I had been taller than most players in the professional league since I was fifteen, but I needed to gain weight to match my height. My coach knew a team that would take me while I was still in college, so I joined them and have never regretted it."

Text: "Seven years ago, I was studying Tourism at college, but I needed a part-time job because my course was expensive. After thinking about different options, I decided to train as a weekend tour guide in my home city, Chicago, USA. This job involved showing visitors around the city, and I was surprised by how much I enjoyed it. I got to see the city I had lived in my whole life from the perspective of tourists, and it felt like a new experience every time!

After I finished my studies, I chose to become a full-time tour guide. I thought it would be easy, but when I researched what I needed to do, I found out that to get a license as a full-time tour guide, I had to learn a lot more than I had so far. All tour guides in Chicago must answer many questions about the city, including its architecture, history, and public transport rules.

After several challenging but interesting months, I earned my tour guide qualification and registered as an independent tour guide. Being a tour guide is not just about knowing historical facts or keeping track of your group in crowds. There are many other important skills. You need to be entertaining and tell interesting stories. Most importantly, you must be able to handle unexpected situations, like if a place you planned to visit is closed or if the route changes. Tourists do not want to hear about problems; they just want to enjoy a well-organized tour.

I need to ensure that visitors are happy with my tours, or they might leave a negative review online. Like most tour guides, I know that these reviews are very important because good reviews attract more customers. That’s why it is essential to make tours fun and stress-free. For me, the enthusiasm and energy I put into my job mean that my reviews are usually very good, and my tours are often recommended to other visitors coming to Chicago."

Text: "My name is Ella, and I am 22 years old. Last year, I went to Thailand for two weeks with my sister Josie. Even though she is five years younger than me, we have a good relationship. We went to volunteer at an elephant sanctuary, which is a place where people care for sick and rescued elephants. At first, I was unsure if we would get along with the other volunteers because they were much older than us. We were also nervous because it was our first time doing something like this. In the end, we had nothing to worry about. 

One of our main jobs at the sanctuary was to collect food for the elephants. Elephants eat a lot of grass and banana plants, so this took most of our day. Josie found it very hard work, but seeing the elephants enjoy their food made it worth it for me. We also helped wash the elephants in the river with big brushes and soap. I had a lot of fun, even though I got wetter than the elephants!

The part of the day I looked forward to the most was the evening. By moonlight, we led the elephants into the forest where they spent the night. All the volunteers stayed in the same house. Josie and I shared a bedroom, which was a bit small, but we chose to do that because Josie didn’t want to be alone. It was hot and humid, especially at night, but we expected that. The meals were delicious and did not include meat, which we both do not like. After dinner, all the volunteers and staff spent the evenings talking and playing games.

Now that we are back in the UK, Josie does not often talk about Thailand. But if someone asks her if she enjoyed her time at the sanctuary, she says she loved it. However, I think she might be a little annoyed with herself for not enjoying her time fully because she missed her friends too much. But when she thinks back, she can see how lucky she was to go there. Maybe she will go back one day – I definitely will!"

Text: "My name is Gina D’Costa, and I own a flower shop in the UK. We sell flowers not just to people for their homes or gifts, but to many different customers. Hotels and offices often use flowers in their reception areas, and we sometimes provide flowers for businesses' advertising photos. Once, I even decorated a castle for a wedding, which was a lot of work, but I felt very proud of what we accomplished.

My day starts at 4 a.m. when I go to the market to buy fresh flowers. Most people are still asleep at that time, and my friends think I’m a bit crazy, but I love what I do. It can be cold and dark, but I don’t let that bother me. The flower market is amazing, with flowers from all over the world. The sights and smells make it hard to choose. If I were buying for myself, I would choose only pink flowers because it’s my favorite color. However, I have to remember that my preferences are not always what customers want. Not all flowers are available all year, so I can’t always find what customers ask for.

I don’t enjoy arguing about prices with the flower sellers, but it’s part of the job. Flowers can be expensive, so I try to get the best price I can. When I return to the shop, we look at customer orders and prepare vases with the flowers I bought. Then, we create flower arrangements and calculate the costs. Customers are often surprised by the prices, and sometimes I have to ask them to reconsider their choices. Some people might think this is too much work, but I enjoy finding the best flowers for the budget someone has. That’s what selling is about, and I wouldn’t want to do anything else!"

My city has a modern cinema that shows all the latest films, including many for kids on weekends. It is close to my home, but a year ago, I realized I wanted something more – the chance to talk about a film in detail with others after watching it. So, I started a film club with two friends! We decided not to rent a cinema. Instead, we choose a different place in the city each month. For example, we used an old factory to show a film set in Antarctica. It was very cold, which made the atmosphere perfect for the film, and it was fantastic! Some places we use are free because the owners sell snacks during the film, allowing us to keep our prices low. We are happy to cover our costs and not make a profit. Each time we show a film, it gets easier, especially now that we have our own reliable equipment. We can also see how many tickets we’ve sold online, so we don’t worry about empty seats anymore! There is still a lot to do, but when people of all ages tell us at the end how much they enjoyed the experience, it feels great. Our website has been very helpful, and we are now in touch with other film clubs across the country. We have visited them to see how they do things, but it’s always nice to return to our own club! We also started a blog because we know most people look online for film information instead of reading local paper reviews. We have tried putting up posters in cafés, but nothing is as effective as word of mouth – when people tell their friends about us. The audience loves the special activities we organize with each film. Last month, we had a movie quiz that everyone enjoyed.

Text: "Taking photographs was always my favorite activity when I was a child. When I turned 15, I wanted to improve my hobby, so I decided to start a special project: I would take one photograph every day for a whole year. Many other young photographers had done this before, but I thought it was a great idea, so I began. After a few weeks, I decided to share my photos on a website for young photographers. I wanted to create a photo diary and show my work to others. I was surprised to find that people liked my way of seeing and photographing things. I enjoyed taking pictures of many different subjects. Then someone suggested that if my photos had a common theme, my project would be even better. I agreed and started focusing on nature scenes, especially birds and the sky. Most of my photos were black and white, which was different from what many other young photographers were doing, as they were taking color photos. Because of this, I sometimes doubted my project and almost gave up. However, I learned to trust my feelings and became more confident in my style and choices. One day, I showed my project to my art teacher. She told me about a national photography competition for my age group, so I entered some of my photos just for fun. I will never forget the moment when the judges told me I had won first prize; I was so happy because my project meant a lot to me. It was the first time I realized that my photography might be good, and that I could work as a professional photographer. Now, I have my own photography studio, and I have never regretted my career choice."

Text: "I joined the National Youth Challenge (NYC) last year because I wanted to try new activities like camping, sailing, and public speaking. In the NYC, you can take part in different activities that help you learn and challenge yourself. There are levels from beginner to advanced, and adult volunteers called ‘leaders’ run the programs. When you finish each level, you receive a certificate.

When I first joined, my leader suggested that I help organize activities at a local children’s club for two hours a week. I was unsure about this because I had joined that same club when I was eight and found it hard to make friends. I was shy, and the other children already had their own friends, so I stopped going after a few weeks. However, I decided to take the challenge because I wanted my first NYC certificate. 

Soon, I started to enjoy spending time at the children’s club much more than just getting the certificate. After I finished the challenge, the NYC leader allowed me to continue volunteering at the club because I had made good friendships with the children. Now, I go there for about four hours a week, and I always look forward to it.

Because of what I learned at the children’s club, I have decided that when I finish school in three years, I want to go to college to become a qualified youth worker, which means working with children. I had never thought about this job before joining the club. This experience has been my favorite part of the NYC, and I have improved my communication skills while helping others. I now have several NYC certificates, and one of them is for camping!"

Text: "I was born in Denver, USA, and I started snowboarding when I was eight years old. My dad took me to a resort in the mountains, about two hours from Denver. The hill looked very steep, so my dad had to convince me to try snowboarding. I was too young to ask him if I could start, but he loved snowboarding and wanted me to enjoy it too. He made it look easy, and in the end, I did well. After that, I quickly fell in love with the sport and got better at it. I began competing when I was ten. Some people enter many competitions and get bored, but my love for competing and winning has grown as I’ve gotten older, which helps me push myself more. I like not having a strict plan, and sometimes this works out well, like when I became the first female to get a perfect score of 100 at a local competition. I wasn’t sure I would try the jumps that got me this score until I actually started. That achievement made me trust my abilities more. 

In the summer, I focus on training and my studies when there’s no snow. I train every day, but it’s nice not to follow a strict diet like I do in winter. I also spend a lot of time with my friends during this time. It helps me cope with not being able to do what I love and what I’m good at. I need to think about my future. Snowboarding is a big part of my life now, but I also think it’s important to have another option in case I don’t become a professional snowboarder or if I get injured. I’m considering whether becoming a doctor is possible if my active life allows time for college. I can’t imagine getting tired of snowboarding, but I know I can’t do it forever."

Text: "When I was fifteen, I wanted everything my friends had, and I never thought about the future. For example, I didn’t know what I wanted to do after school. One day, my best friend got a new phone for her birthday, and I thought I should have one too. My parents said I could only get it if I paid for it myself, so I decided to work part-time and save money. I am grateful to my parents for making me do that because it taught me an important lesson. I worked every Saturday in a café, but I didn’t enjoy it much, so my parents suggested I start my own small business. I had seen my mum making necklaces, so I asked if I could try that. I never thought it would be so easy, as it looked complicated when I watched my mum. My friends thought it sounded boring, but I was excited about it. My mum showed me that I could create something nice at home with simple tools and materials. I sold my first pieces of jewellery to my friends and family as soon as I finished making them. They said they loved them, but I thought they were just being nice. Even though I was happy they bought them, I still needed to know if they would be popular with other people. The only way to find out was to rent a market stall with my mum. There are many tourists where I live, and they bought a lot of my items to take home. Soon, we started getting calls from all over the country from people wanting to buy more. They thought we were a big company with many workers, but we were just two people at a market stall! That was when I realized it could work, and it was time to take the next step – creating a website. Since then, I’ve made thousands of pounds from my business, mostly online, but we still have our stall too. It has been a lot of fun so far."

Text: 'When Janine Stuart was just 13 years old, she wrote a novel called Being Amelia, which became a bestseller. The book is partly based on Janine’s own life. In an interview, Janine explained, “Because my father’s job made us move around the country a lot, I learned how to make new friends easily. I know what it’s like to be the new student in a class, and that helped me write about how the main character, Amelia, adjusts to a new school. Some of the funniest parts of the book are about Amelia’s home life, especially her relationship with her older brother. Since I am an only child, I had to use my imagination to describe that.” 

Janine started writing her novel one summer when she was bored at home. Her mother had always wanted to be a published author, and her teachers encouraged her to write, so it felt natural for Janine to spend her time this way. The year before, she had entered a short story competition on a young writers’ website and won first prize. This is why, when Janine finished Being Amelia and sent it to a publishing company, they were eager to read it. They loved the book, and a year later, it was available in bookstores. 

One review of Being Amelia notes that, even though the cover shows happy teenagers, the characters face real challenges, which makes them believable. The reviewer mentions that, although Janine is still very young and her novel is not very long, she has shown that she is a better writer than many other bestselling authors. Janine is still adjusting to being a famous writer: “At first, I would hide when people recognized me in the street, but now it’s fine. I want to give advice to other young writers, but they need to find what works for them. For me, I just need to spend time with my friends, and I will soon have something interesting to write about!”'

Text: "My name is Tom, and I am fifteen years old. Three years ago, my family and I moved to a castle on a small island. This happened because my father was invited to manage the castle. He works for a group that takes care of historical buildings and keeps them open for visitors. He was happy to get this opportunity, but it took some time for the rest of us to agree that he should take the job. We were worried about what life on the island would be like. We knew the castle might not be as comfortable as our warm home across the water, and there was no school nearby.

After we moved, we quickly adjusted to life on the island. The castle is not very beautiful, but our apartment in it is nice. In the summer, the island is lively with many visitors, and there are often beach parties. In winter, we mostly see the other families who live here, but there are not many teenagers, which I had hoped for. The adults help each other with repairs on the island, which can be hard work.

The biggest change for me was taking a boat every day to my old school. I looked forward to going on stormy days when there are big waves, but the ferries do not run then! I also learned that if I miss the bus to the harbor after school, I will miss the last ferry home, which is stressful. So, when my friends come to visit, I always tell them to hurry! However, we often see amazing views, especially when the sun sets over the sea. Some days, it is so foggy that you cannot see anything, but then it can become sunny again within hours, which still surprises me even after living here for a while. We do have terrible storms sometimes, and I wonder if the castle is strong enough to stay safe. But then I remember it has been here for hundreds of years and is still standing!"

I live in a house in the beautiful countryside of Scotland. I have always loved nature and wild animals. Six years ago, I started a new hobby: birdwatching! I went to the mountains in northern Scotland with my family, where we saw many birds in their natural habitat. I spent hours watching them with my parents, who taught me how to identify different species and find the best places to see them. It was amazing! After returning home, I joined a local birdwatchers’ club for young people. My goal is to see 200 different bird species, and I am close to achieving that. During family holidays abroad, I have seen birds from other countries as well. We always look for places with group birdwatching activities so I can add new birds to my list! 

I have been to Egypt, and last summer we went to South America, where I thought I would see my 200th species. I was not too disappointed when it didn’t happen because I learned that patience is important in this hobby. I posted a video online about this challenge, and many teenagers liked it and said it looked like a fascinating hobby. When my teachers saw it, they asked me to give a presentation about birdwatching at school. I felt nervous just before I walked onto the stage, but I knew what to say and had some notes to help me. I only relaxed when it was over, and the teachers said I had prepared well and they enjoyed it. I might even do another presentation next year!

I am lucky to live in the countryside. I understand why many teenagers in cities might not think about becoming birdwatchers, but there are many birds to see, especially in areas with lots of green spaces. I believe that birdwatching clubs should try to attract more young people to this hobby. Everyone needs to connect with nature, no matter their age, and it doesn’t have to cost much money.

Text: "I started playing football when I was 7 years old. I would hurry home from school to play with other kids. I loved it, and after some time, I became a good player. My family knew I often got excited about new hobbies and then lost interest, so they thought I would do the same with football. But that never happened. I even dreamed of playing football professionally when I grew up. The chance came sooner than I expected. I played in local tournaments, and one referee saw that I was a talented player. He asked the manager of a professional women’s club to watch me play. After that, she invited me to join her club. I was surprised because I didn’t know young girls could join women’s clubs. But the manager liked my skills, and I started training regularly with a big club when I was just 13 years old. I improved a lot after that. Still, some people were not sure I would become a star player, which made me a little sad. But my coach encouraged me to be myself and believe in my abilities. He even let me play in one of the club’s championship matches earlier than I thought I would! I ran harder than ever because I didn’t want to let my teammates down. Then, by chance, I scored the winning goal. Even with a large crowd, I could hear my coach cheering for me, and after the match, my team carried me around the field. It was amazing! Since then, I have scored many more winning goals! Next month, my coach and I are organizing a football tournament in my area. The goal is to get teenagers interested in football and give them a chance to meet other players from my club. It will show them what a professional environment is like and encourage them to believe they can play for a top team if they work hard. My advice to them will be the same as my coach gave me – there will be good times, but also some bad times. I’ve had very few bad times, though, so I feel lucky!"

Text: 

In recent years, there has been an interesting change in further and higher education in the UK and around the world. More and more, students are being encouraged to get involved in research early in their studies. This change shows that research is not just for famous scholars or scientists, but is a natural way to build knowledge and skills. Research skills are important not only for your studies but also for your future job, as they help you think about the world and how to do your work.

As a student, you contribute to knowledge. You do not just learn and repeat information; you create it. Creating knowledge starts with asking questions instead of just accepting things as they are. You might wonder: Why? How? When? What does this mean? What if things were different? How does it work in this situation? What should we think about the facts, views, or beliefs we are given? Why is this important? These questions are at the heart of what we call research.

Research can be seen as a range of activities. On one end, there is complex and groundbreaking research done by highly trained experts, which leads to significant changes in knowledge. However, research can also start from simple questions and everyday inquiries. This type of research involves careful work, asking thoughtful questions about issues, and making practical suggestions.

Most students have always done some form of research. You have likely conducted research for school projects or answered questions at work since you started. You have asked questions that led you to investigate topics, whether it was about where to go on holiday, how to grow plants, or how to fix things at home. In college and higher education, it is expected that you will have an enquiring mind, identify problems, critically explore information, and create your own knowledge to contribute to discussions.

Some students may find this challenging because, in some cultures, knowledge is seen as fixed. In these places, students learn by listening to teachers and texts without questioning them. It may feel disrespectful to challenge established knowledge or authority. However, in higher education in the UK, US, much of Europe, and Australia, questioning established knowledge and authorities is encouraged.

This process of inquiry and knowledge creation can seem overwhelming. Critical thinking is very important in research. The research done by others is valuable for students and professionals, but we must not just repeat what we read as if it is always true. We need to engage with the information, think critically about it, and check if it is logical and supported by evidence. We should avoid blindly accepting facts and information from our readings or conversations.

Text: 

Cities have always been important places for ideas and creativity. In the 18th century, coffee houses in London were popular spots where people discussed science and politics. In modern Paris, cafés on the Left Bank were where artists like Pablo Picasso talked about art. However, living in a city can be challenging. The same cafés that encouraged discussions also helped spread diseases like cholera, and Picasso eventually moved to the countryside. 

Today, cities are known for their creativity, but they can also feel overwhelming and unnatural. Recent studies show that city life can actually make it harder for us to think clearly. One major reason for this is the lack of nature in cities. Research has shown that hospital patients recover faster when they can see trees from their windows. Even small views of nature can help our brains relax and improve our thinking.

For the first time in history, more people live in cities than in rural areas. Instead of being in open spaces, we are often surrounded by many strangers in crowded places. This unnatural environment can affect our mental and physical health and change how we think. For example, when walking down a busy street, our brains have to pay attention to many things: people, traffic, and confusing street layouts. These small tasks can tire us out because cities are full of distractions that require us to constantly focus.

This idea is explained by attention restoration theory, developed by psychologist Stephen Kaplan. He suggested that being in nature can help restore our attention. Natural environments have things that naturally attract our focus without causing stress, unlike loud noises like police sirens. When we are in nature, our minds can relax and recharge.

Long before scientists studied this, philosophers and landscape designers warned about the negative effects of city life and sought ways to bring nature into urban areas. Parks, like Central Park in New York, provide a break from city life. A well-designed park can help our brains function better in just a few minutes. While people have tried many methods to improve mental performance, such as energy drinks or office redesigns, nothing seems to work as well as simply taking a walk in nature.

Despite the mental challenges of city life, cities continue to grow. Research from the Santa Fe Institute shows that the same crowded features of cities that can hurt our attention and memory also encourage innovation. The close social interactions in cities are key to their creativity. Just as the crowded streets of 18th-century London led to new ideas, the busy environment of 21st-century Cambridge, Massachusetts, helps it thrive as a center for technology. On the other hand, less crowded areas may produce fewer new ideas over time.

The challenge is to find ways to reduce the negative effects of city living while keeping its benefits. As the saying goes, there comes a time when someone might say, "I'm tired of nature; take me to the city!"

**Simplified Text:**

Where should we look for the mind? This question may seem strange because we usually think that thinking happens inside our heads. Today, we have advanced brain imaging techniques that support this idea. However, I believe that studying the mind should not be limited to just what is inside our bodies. There is a lot of evidence, from ancient times to now, showing that objects, as well as our brain cells, play a role in how we think. 

From an archaeological perspective, items like stone tools, jewelry, carvings, clay tokens, and writing systems have been important in human evolution and the development of our minds. Therefore, what is outside our heads might also be part of our minds. It is easy to connect the mind with the brain because most of what we know about the mind comes from studying people without the objects they usually use. This makes sense for neuroscientists who need to use brain-scanning machines. However, this often overlooks the fact that much of our thinking happens outside our heads. 

I do not want to deny that our brain is important for thinking, but I want to highlight that the mind is more than just the brain. It is better to explore the idea that human intelligence extends beyond our bodies into culture and the material world. This is where my new theory, called Material Engagement Theory (MET), comes in. MET looks at how objects can become extensions of our thinking or be used by our bodies, like when we make symbols from clay or use a stone to create a tool. It also examines how these interactions have changed over time and what these changes mean for our thinking.

This approach gives us new insights into what minds are and how they work by changing our understanding of the role of objects in our thinking. For example, think of a blind person using a stick. Where does this person’s self begin? The connection between the blind person and the stick shows how minds and objects can be linked, and it illustrates the flexibility of the human mind. By using the stick, the blind person can turn touch into a form of sight, and the stick itself plays an important role. The brain treats the stick as part of the body.

The blind person’s stick reminds us that human intelligence can change significantly by using new technologies. I see the human mind as a work in progress, always evolving. It is important to remember that whatever form the “stick” has taken throughout history—whether it is a simple stone tool or a modern smartphone—its main purpose is to connect us to the world, not to separate us from it. 

For humans, “sticks” are tools we use to satisfy our curiosity. This special ability to engage with objects explains why humans create things more than any other species, and how these creations shape our minds. I call this idea metaplasticity, meaning our minds can change and develop as they interact with the material world. I want to emphasize the importance of material objects in understanding the mind. MET provides a new way to see how different types of objects, from ancient tools to modern devices, have helped define and change who we are and how we think. While the idea of technology changing our minds may sound futuristic, it is important to realize that humans have been using such technology since the beginning of our existence.

Text: "Few inventions have changed our way of understanding the world as much as photography. This is especially true in the United States, where photography quickly became part of culture at all levels – from practical and scientific uses to industrial and artistic ones, as well as entertainment. Historians argue that photography is one of the greatest contributions of the US to the visual arts. No other art form has had such a significant impact from the US. This claim shows that photography has become central to American culture, and to understand its impact, we need to look at its beginnings in the mid-19th century.

Why was photography so appealing? First, photography was a mechanical process that matched the growing interest in technology, reflecting a national attitude that accepted change. Just like steam power, railroads, and electricity made communication and travel easier, photography brought the wonders of the world into people's homes in an exciting way. Second, the camera became a popular tool for representing oneself, allowing people to create images for public viewing in a society where personal and national identities were constantly being formed and reformed. Third, the camera has been important for families, providing a way to keep a record of their lives, even if that record is somewhat idealized. Finally, the realistic nature of photographs matched the trend towards realism in the work of US artists.

Every photograph draws attention to something specific, showing what the photographer wants us to see. Because photographs are made by machines, they are records of events, people, or things, which gives them a sense of objectivity. However, since each photograph is taken by a person, it also carries a personal point of view. We might look at a photograph and think we understand its meaning, leading to the idea that photography is a 'universal language.' But the meaning of a photograph is more complicated than that. Few subjects – whether a person, object, or event – have their own clear meaning, and every image comes with some context that shapes our understanding of it, like a caption in a newspaper or its placement in a gallery.

To understand a photograph historically, we need to consider its purpose and function in its cultural context: Why did the photographer take the picture? How did people first see it? Additionally, the same image can be viewed in different places and times, changing its meaning each time. While the importance of the camera to artists was not widely recognized for a long time, it is now clear. In recent decades, starting with artist Andy Warhol's use of photographs in his work, many artists have included photographs in various ways. In summary, photography has become an essential part of art, complementing painting and shaping our ideas of representation before the camera was invented."

In 1890, William James, an American philosopher and one of the founders of modern psychology, defined psychology as the "science of mental life." This definition is still relevant today. We all have a mental life, which gives us some understanding of what this means. Although we can study mental life in animals like rats and monkeys, it is still a complex idea. James focused mainly on human psychology, which he believed included basic elements: thoughts, feelings, the physical world, and a way to understand these elements. Our knowledge about these things is mostly personal and comes from our own experiences, which may or may not be influenced by scientific facts.

Because of this, we often make judgments about psychological issues based on our own experiences. We act like amateur psychologists when we share our opinions on complex topics, such as whether brainwashing works or why people behave in certain ways. Problems can arise when two people understand things differently. Formal psychology aims to provide methods to determine which explanations are most likely correct in different situations. Psychologists help us separate subjective thoughts, which can be biased, from objective facts.

Psychology, as defined by William James, is about the mind and brain. While psychologists study the brain, they do not yet fully understand how it works in relation to our hopes, fears, and behaviors. It is often difficult to study the brain directly, so psychologists learn more by observing behavior and forming hypotheses about what happens inside us. A challenge in psychology is that scientific facts should be objective, but the mind's workings are not easily observable. We can only understand them indirectly through behavior.

Studying psychology is similar to solving a crossword puzzle. It requires evaluating and interpreting clues, which must come from careful observation and accurate measurement. These observations need to be analyzed rigorously and interpreted logically. Psychology often involves complex interactions, and understanding them requires advanced techniques and theories. Like any other science, psychology aims to describe, understand, predict, and learn how to influence the processes it studies. Achieving these goals can help us understand our experiences and apply this knowledge to improve people's lives.

Psychological findings have been useful in many areas, such as improving teaching methods, designing safer machines, and helping people express their feelings better. Although psychological questions have been discussed for centuries, they have only been studied scientifically for the last 150 years. Early psychologists used introspection, or self-reflection, to answer psychological questions. They aimed to identify mental structures, which is still important today. However, introspection has limitations, as noted by Sir Francis Galton, who said it only allows us to see a small part of what the brain does automatically. William James compared trying to understand the mind through introspection to "turning up the gas quickly enough to see how the darkness looks." Today, psychologists prefer to base their theories on careful observations of others' behavior rather than on their own experiences.

In a storehouse in a regular business park in Michigan, USA, there is a unique collection known as the Museum of Failed Products. This museum, owned by a company called GfK, displays products that were taken off the market because very few people wanted to buy them. The owner, Carol Sherry, believes that each product has its own story of disappointment for the designers and marketers involved. 

What is surprising is that this museum exists as a successful business. Many companies do not keep samples of their failed products, showing how uncomfortable they are with failure. The museum was started by Robert McMath, who originally wanted to create a library of consumer products, not just failed ones. He began collecting every new item he could find in the 1960s. He soon realized a key truth: most products fail. By collecting all kinds of products, he ended up with mostly unsuccessful ones.

Today’s positive culture may contribute to the products in the museum. Many products likely went through meetings where no one recognized their potential failure. Even if they did, marketers might invest more money into a failing product to save face. There is often little effort to understand why these products failed, and people involved may choose to forget about it.

This focus on optimism is also common in the self-help industry. One popular idea is "positive visualization," which suggests that imagining good outcomes can help make them happen. Research by neuroscientist Tali Sharot shows that a healthy mind may be inclined to see positive outcomes as more likely than they actually are. Her studies suggest that well-adjusted people often have an overly optimistic view of their ability to influence events compared to those who are depressed.

However, how effective are these positive thoughts about the future? Psychologist Gabriele Oettingen and her team have studied this question. Their findings are surprising: thinking too much about how well things could go can actually reduce people's motivation to reach their goals. For example, people who were encouraged to imagine having a very successful week at work ended up achieving less.

Psychologist Carol Dweck explains that our experiences with failure depend on our beliefs about ability. People with a "fixed mindset" believe that ability is something you are born with, while those with a "growth mindset" think that ability can develop through effort and challenges. Fixed-mindset individuals find failure very frightening because it shows they did not meet expectations. For instance, a talented athlete who believes they are naturally gifted may not practice enough to reach their full potential. In contrast, growth-mindset individuals see failure as a sign that they are pushing their limits. Dweck compares this to weight training, where muscles grow stronger by being challenged. Overall, having a growth mindset is a healthier way to approach life, regardless of whether it leads to success.

Text: 

Everyone knows that sports teams have an advantage when they play at home. But why is that? Many people think they understand it, but professional sports are changing quickly, and what we used to believe is now being questioned. Two main factors are making us rethink home advantage: science and money. Sports scientists want to discover what helps players perform their best, and they have come up with many theories about home advantage. At the same time, those who invest in sports want to know why home advantage is still important. If players are paid well, shouldn’t they feel comfortable playing anywhere?

This raises a question for fans. Would it matter if a team like Manchester United played some of their home games in the Far East to reach more fans there? It would matter to British fans, who believe their team needs their support and loyalty. Fans often think that the order of events explains what happens. For example, when a team attacks, the home fans cheer loudly, and sometimes this leads to a goal. Fans remember the times they cheered and a goal was scored, but they forget the many times when their cheering did not lead to success.

However, there is one common belief among fans that is supported by scientific evidence. Home fans not only cheer for their team but also direct a lot of their noise at the referee. In a well-known experiment, referees watched a match with crowd noise and another group watched the same match in silence. The referees who heard the crowd were less likely to call fouls against the home team than those who watched in silence. Interestingly, the crowd noise did not make them more likely to call fouls against the away team. The researchers concluded that referees try to avoid extra stress from making calls against the home team.

Recent studies show that home advantage has decreased in all major sports, but not as much as expected. For example, in the early years of the Football League in the 1890s in England, home teams won about 70% of the points, while today they win about 60%. One reason for this change could be travel. In the past, traveling was difficult, but now players travel in comfort, and if their hotel is not good enough, the club will find them a better one. Stadiums used to be very different from each other, but now many top stadiums look similar and lack character.

Despite these explanations, none fully explains the data. Home advantage varies by sport. Basketball has the most home advantage, followed by football, while baseball has the least. One reason could be that home advantage is more about teamwork, and baseball focuses more on individual matchups between the batter and pitcher. In team sports like basketball, winning depends on teamwork, which builds confidence when playing at home.

Another possibility relates to the players' emotions. Researchers found that players’ testosterone levels were normal before away games but increased by up to 67% before home games. This feeling of defending their home may connect to a basic instinct to protect their territory. In recent Rugby World Cup games, underdog teams playing at home won against stronger opponents, showing the power of home advantage. As one referee said, "It’s the law of the jungle out there."

Text: "‘The more I practice, the luckier I get,’ said golfer Gary Player about fifty years ago. This saying is popular among many dedicated athletes and their coaches. The reason for its popularity is clear. First, there is some debate about who originally said it, as many golfers from that time have been suggested. Second, the meaning of the quote is not straightforward. Player did not mean luck in a literal sense; he was being ironic. His real message was: ‘The more I practice, the better I get.’ 

However, there is a limit to this idea. The question of where that limit is, or if it even exists, relates to the nature-nurture debate. This debate discusses whether talent is something we are born with or something we develop through practice. It is not really a balanced debate; nurture (the influence of environment and practice) has clearly won. The idea that practice is more important than natural talent in sports, music, business, and other areas comes from psychologist Anders Ericsson. He is known for the theory that it takes 10,000 hours of practice to become an expert in any field. This theory has been popularized in books like Malcolm Gladwell’s Outliers and others with titles like Talent Is Overrated and Bounce: The Myth of Talent and the Power of Practice. These books generally agree that practice is the most important factor, suggesting that ‘10,000 hours is both necessary and enough to make anyone an expert in anything.’

However, as Epstein discusses in his interesting book, this idea is often not true. He points out a major problem in much of the research on excellence: it usually focuses only on successful people. He asks if there are better ways to understand why some people have certain abilities while others do not, and how to separate natural talent from what is learned through environment, support, and hard work. Epstein travels around the world, from Kenya to Sweden and the Caribbean to the Arctic, to find answers. In Alaska, he discovers that the success of sled dogs in tough races may depend on their drive and desire, suggesting a link between genetics and traits we think are voluntary.

This raises the question: can determination and commitment be chosen, or are they influenced by genetics? Epstein believes that the topic is complex. He makes a distinction between ‘hardware’ (nature) and ‘software’ (nurture), and he agrees that both are important for elite athletes. He does not ignore the role of training or environment. For example, he suggests that if Usain Bolt had grown up in the US, he might have become a good basketball player instead of the fastest man in history. However, Epstein also looks at cases where genetics play a significant role that cannot be overlooked. He also discusses important issues like race and gender. He asks: ‘If only practice matters, why do we separate men and women in sports competitions?’ Sometimes, the best questions are the most obvious."
