When I ask my literature students what a poem is, they often say things like "a painting in words." Their answers usually do not satisfy me or them. One day, I asked a group to pick an object and write two paragraphs about it. The first paragraph was a scientific description, and the second was from the object's point of view, titled "Poem." One student wrote: 

**Poem**  
I may look strange or scary, but I’m a device that helps people breathe. I’m only used in emergencies and for a short time. Most people will never need to use me. The object? An oxygen mask – an unusual choice that helped the class understand how poetry works in a unique way. This exercise led to laughter and helpful discussions.

When I was in school, poetry often confused me. I thought every poem was a silly puzzle that made it hard to understand and feel. After school, most people pay less attention to poetry. Sometimes you see a poem, and it stands out because it is not continuous prose. It challenges you to read it, but often you feel let down by its simplicity or because you don’t understand it at first. Still, you feel good for trying.

What do we hope to find in poems? Isn’t a poem a place for deep feelings, beautiful images, thoughtful reflections, or sharp humor? The answer seems to be yes. But if we want tears, we watch movies; for information or sharp criticism, we read online articles. Novels let us escape, paintings please our eyes, and music – well, nothing can compare to the beauty of lyrics, instruments, and melody.

However, one useful thing a poem can offer is ambiguity. Everyday life is full of uncertainty, unlike reading sentence by sentence. But these thoughts still don’t explain what a poem really is. If you search online for "poem," it leads you to "poetry," which is described as "a form of literary art that uses the beauty and rhythm of language." This sounds nice, but it doesn’t explain the word’s origins. "Poem" comes from the Greek word poí?ma, meaning "a thing made," and a poet is someone who "makes things." So, if a poem is a thing made, what kind of thing is it?

Poets sometimes compare poems to wild animals – untameable and unpredictable – or to machines – carefully designed and exact – depending on their views. But these comparisons often break down when examined closely. The most valuable part of trying to define a poem through comparison is not the comparison itself but the discussion it creates. Whether you see a poem as a machine or a wild animal, this process can change how you think about both. It can help us rethink our usual ways of thinking and see ordinary things in a new way.

A poem as a mental object is easy to understand, especially when we think about how song lyrics can stick in our minds. The mix of words and melody has a strong effect, going back to schoolyard rhymes like "Sticks and stones may break my bones, but words can never hurt me." But aren’t words sometimes like sticks and stones? Think about a poem on a page of a newspaper or magazine, right in front of you: A poem can touch you like nothing else, even though it is just ink on paper, like the prose around it. 

What about all the empty space around the poem – space that could have been used for a longer article or an ad? A poem is written and rewritten just like an article, story, or novel, but it is not usually made to be sold. Publishers write press releases and send out review copies of poetry collections, but few expect them to make money. A poem is not just a product for the market; it exists for its own sake. Because of its special place in a magazine or book, a poem can still surprise us, even if just for a moment.

Text: 

I bought my first metal detector soon after I got married. At that time, £70 was a lot of money, and I could have spent it on something useful for our home. However, my wife, Marion, was impressed when I found a gold ring worth £80 on my first outing. Over the years, every brooch and coin I discovered brought me joy. I have always enjoyed feeling connected to the past. 

After the gold ring, it took 40 years before I found something that impressed Marion again. It was a dull February afternoon, and I had a couple of hours to spare. I had a place in mind, but it was raining, so I decided to go to a nearby spot that I knew had old farming machinery. 

When my detector first beeped, I found a piece of a metal wheel. Then, it beeped again. I tried to ignore it, but I couldn’t walk away without checking. I dug down about half a meter and was lying in the mud when I saw a rounded, golden ball. I had found brass curtain rails before, so I tried not to get my hopes up. But as I cleaned it, I realized it was a beautiful, patterned loop. I stopped and stared, remembering the Great Torc I had seen in the British Museum. It is a famous piece from Iron Age Britain, over 2,000 years old. A torc is a twisted necklace made of gold and silver, with gold rings at each end, just like the one I was holding.

I took it to my car and kept looking at it on the way home. I rinsed it in my kitchen sink, probably the first time it had been cleaned in centuries. “Marion!” I shouted, “I have something for you.” When she came into the room, she stopped and asked, “What is it?” I told her it was a very old and rare piece of jewelry. We didn’t try it on because we were afraid of damaging it. At bedtime, I hid it in our wardrobe. Even though we had never been robbed, I felt anxious. Later, I got up and hid it under a floorboard in my office.

The law says that I must report such finds to the authorities within 14 days. I wanted to enjoy the torc as much as I could before giving it up. I even took it in a plastic bag to show a friend in the hospital. Finally, I took it to the council office in the same bag. The registrar was talking to someone when I placed the torc on his desk. He turned around, stopped talking, and looked at it. The torc was confirmed as authentic and was eventually sold to my local council. It is now in the British Museum in London. The £350,000 from the sale was shared between the owner of the field and me. 

But the torc means more to me than just money. I feel like I have saved it for the nation. People often ask me, “Now that you found something so amazing, will you stop detecting?” But I still find brooches and coins interesting. Just like a fisherman who catches a big fish, I won’t stop looking for more treasures.

Text: "Sleeping is one of my favorite things about traveling, but I don’t talk about it much because I feel a bit guilty. When my friends share stories about their carefully planned trips, where every moment is filled with activities like visiting museums or hiking, I just smile and don’t say much. What would they think if they knew that my travel plans often include long naps during afternoon rainstorms and lazy mornings in comfortable beds? Better sleep is one of the nice benefits of traveling. When I went to Mexico's Yucatán coast in my early 20s, I was surprised by how many hours – more than 12 – I spent sleeping each day. There were many loud birds nearby, but it didn’t bother me. Away from home and my own bed, surrounded by new smells and sounds, I could sleep deeply and enjoyably. Without alarm clocks and responsibilities, sleep comes more easily. But I think there is more to travel sleep than just relaxing. I believe that sleep is part of our travel experience, not just a break from it. When we travel, we experience new sights, sounds, smells, and ways of living. All this new information fills us up – different cultures, music, landscapes, and ways of moving. When we sleep, we process this flood of new experiences. It makes sense that sleep feels more intense when we are traveling. Sleep also changes in different places. People often worry about jet lag, but I think the challenges I face after long trips are more about adjusting to local cultures than just time differences. For example, on the Caribbean island of Trinidad, people wake up early to avoid the heat, slow down around 10 a.m. when the sun is strong, and then become active again in the cool evening. Even though Trinidad is only one hour ahead of New York, where I live, it takes me days to get used to the island’s different sleep patterns. When I finally adjust, I feel like I have truly arrived. I remember one afternoon in Santo Domingo, the capital of the Dominican Republic, when I had a big lunch with new Dominican friends in an apartment with a view of the blue Caribbean Sea. After eating, we all felt sleepy, and the conversation faded away. One by one, my friends left the table to lie down on hammocks and sofas. I realized why they had so many pillows on the floor. I took some for myself and followed their lead. I had heard about the Latin American tradition of the siesta, but that day I really experienced it. I shared not just sleep, but a piece of Dominican life. Travel sleep has another great quality: I remember it. Away from my usual sleep routine, I enjoy the new smells, textures, and sounds that fill my mind while I sleep in a new place. If the idea of ‘slow travel’ – enjoying every moment instead of rushing around – is what makes a modern traveler aware, then what is slower than sleep? Maybe I should stop feeling embarrassed about my love for sleep and tell my ambitious friends that travel sleep is, in fact, an important part of the experience."

The woman turned away from the mirror. “What do you think? Be honest.” Mia picked up a medium-sized hat that was soft and had a pretty layer of gauze and a silk bow. “I still think this one looks best on you,” she said to her customer, trying to be diplomatic. The woman wrinkled her nose and made a face that made her look like a bulldog. “But it’s so boring,” she said. “Every other woman will wear a hat like that at my daughter’s wedding. This beautiful little hat will make me stand out.” She sighed and touched the red and black miniature top hat on her head. “Yes,” she said firmly, “this is the one I want.” 

Mia knew she couldn’t change the woman’s mind. With a smile, she agreed that the woman would indeed stand out at her daughter’s wedding. Mia then thought about her own daughter, Jen. It was Jen’s thirtieth birthday today, and they were having a family gathering. It had been a while since they had all been together, and Mia was excited to see Jen, Dan, and Luke. She was also looking forward to meeting Jen’s friend, Tattie, whom they didn’t know much about. When Jen called last week to ask if she could bring Tattie, Mia’s husband, Jeff, had quickly reacted. “Tattie? What kind of name is that?” he had said. “It’s short for Tatiana,” Mia replied. “I think it’s nice.” “More like something very pretentious,” Jeff had responded. 

Jeff didn’t like anything that seemed showy. He also didn’t understand Mia’s way of being polite and not saying exactly what she thought. He would have told the woman in the shop that she was choosing the wrong hat. He might have even said that a dustbin lid would look better on her. “The problem with you, Mia,” he often said, “is that you’re too polite for your own good.” 

An hour later, Mia closed her shop and entered through the back door of Medlar House. Her commute from work took only forty seconds. Four years ago, when Luke, their youngest child, left home, Mia decided to turn the unused barn next to their house into a bright space for her business. Jeff was doubtful. “Do you really think people want to buy hats?” he asked. But Mia knew from her friends that many women struggled to find the perfect hat for special occasions, so she was sure there was a demand. She was right. From the first day, after Jen helped her create a website, Mia’s Hats became a success. Women came from far away to her showroom in Little Pelham, where she created a relaxed and welcoming atmosphere. She let customers try on as many hats as they needed to find the right one. She encouraged them to bring their outfits to make sure everything matched. Recently, she had also started selling handbags and costume jewelry.

Text: 

It is a long journey from London to Atlanta, and at his new home in America, Lawrence Okoye reflects on his incredible sports journey. He is confident but seems surprised by how far he has come, from competing in the Olympic discus final to possibly starting a new career. Even though he has never played American football before, Lawrence is likely to be chosen for one of the major teams in the USA. In Atlanta, he is still figuring out what his new position involves.

The idea that a 21-year-old beginner from London could be selected for one of the biggest teams in American sports is surprising. However, Lawrence is known for proving people wrong. He was offered a place at Oxford University to study law but decided to focus on training for the discus instead, after previously playing rugby. Within 20 months of starting, he became the world’s fourth-best discus thrower.

Lawrence originally went to Atlanta for warm-weather training for the discus, preparing for the world championships. When asked about his sudden interest in American football, he says, “It was in the back of my mind, but I only decided to try it when I got to the USA.” He had thought about it while in school in London, but it seemed like a crazy idea at the time. After arriving in America, he learned about the NFL trials in Atlanta. Even though he had never played before, he felt confident enough to apply for the trials. 

When asked if he was nervous about competing against experienced players, he replied, “Not at all. I don’t get nervous for many things.” Although he is not very talkative, he is sure of his abilities. His performance in various tests showed that he was the most impressive player. “I was very happy to hear that,” he said, showing a rare moment of pride.

However, he is also cautious. He has no experience in American football, so how can he make it onto an NFL team? He says, “Coaches have told me I have the right skills. It’s all about how hard I work.” When asked if he will be relaxed while waiting to hear if he has been selected, he said, “I will be. There’s no pressure on me. Many people say I will definitely be chosen, but I’m not too worried.”

This calmness may come from his disappointing experience in the Olympic discus final, where he finished last. He seems to have moved on from that moment and is proud that he qualified for the final with a great last throw. “That was an amazing day,” he said. “The final didn’t go as I wanted, but that’s part of sports. I can always return to it.”

After his Olympic disappointment, some people thought that he had let the experience affect him negatively. Lawrence does not want to comment on that. The minimum salary for an NFL player is over $400,000 a year, which is a strong motivation. So, Lawrence has moved from rugby to athletics and now to American football. With all his physical talent, wouldn’t it be better for him to focus on just one sport? “I understand why someone would say that,” he replied. “I’m trying to achieve something I’ve dreamed about since I was a kid. If it doesn’t work out, I can go back to the discus, the sport I love. Every decision I’ve made has been thought out.”

Text: 'We had been flying east all night, and I woke up to see that it was already daylight. Looking out of the window at the empty land below, the dark shades of brown and green made me feel better. Even though it was mid-September, it had not yet started to change in Siberia. I could see no signs of people, just a strange view of mountains, streams, and forests stretching to the horizon. I shook my head. My neighbor woke up and smiled at me sleepily. “Good morning, Robert,” he said, saying my name with a slow Russian accent. Sergei was a salesman from Moscow flying to the far reaches of civilization to sell safety clothing to local mining companies. His English was almost as poor as my Russian, but with a dictionary, I managed to tell him that I was going to the far-eastern Siberian city of Magadan with a one-way ticket because I planned to return home to England by bicycle. “But, Robert,” he said, “there is no road from Magadan; you cannot ride a bicycle.” I explained that I believed there was a road, even if not many people used it these days. “Alone?” he asked, pointing at me. “No, I will be riding with a friend called Al.” “Just one friend?” “Yes, just one,” I nodded. Sergei still looked unsure and pointed outside, saying “Holodna” (cold). I tried to convince him by using hand gestures to show that I had a lot of warm clothes, but I didn’t mention that I was on a tight budget. Most of my clothes and equipment were bought at low prices. In reality, I was not sure they would be good enough. This was especially true for my large postman’s over-trousers that I had bought for £10. 

It all started in a lecture hall in Scotland. The hall was full of students slumped in their seats. Some were taking notes without much energy. The lecturer was speaking on and on. I was thinking hard about a dilemma. Should I ask him or not? “Well, why not?” I tore a fresh sheet from my pad and wrote, “Hi Al, Do you want to cycle across the Karakorum Highway between Pakistan and China this summer? Rob.” In the row in front of me sat Al, my old school friend. I tapped him on the shoulder and passed the note. He tried to read my handwriting, scratched his head, wrote something, and passed it back. I unfolded it and held my breath while I read. “OK,” it said. 

It was six years later that I was going to meet Al in Siberia. I had been working as a geography teacher, and although I was still learning to manage my classes, the job was good for me. It was often challenging, rarely boring, and sometimes fulfilling, plus there were long holidays to chase adventures. Twice since I started teaching, I had used these holidays to meet Al. He had caught the adventure bug after our bike ride through Pakistan and decided to do something more exciting than teaching: to cycle around the world. Since our first ride together, Al had been taking on bigger challenges. This round-the-world bike trip was certainly his biggest yet. Sometimes he thought the ride would break him. Although it sounded tough, I envied him in many ways. He was having an amazing adventure, proving that he could handle each new challenge, even if it seemed impossible. He was showing the doubters that he could do it. He was doing something that scared him almost every day, and it made him feel alive.'

**Simplified Text:**

In The Red Bull Air Race, twelve pilots take turns racing through tall pylons that are between 15 and 25 meters high. They make sharp turns, barrel rolls, and loops while flying at speeds of up to 370 km per hour. I was invited to experience what it feels like to participate in this race. 

An hour before my flight, I had to sign two forms. The first form confirmed that I was healthy, and the second said I would empty my pockets because small objects can be dangerous during the flight. I learned that I needed to stay aware of my surroundings. “The horizon is your best friend,” the pilot told me, “and I will guide you on where to look.” I also had to promise to relax and enjoy the view when flying upside down.

Half an hour before the flight, I attended a safety briefing where I was told not to touch anything. As we were getting ready to take off, I was nervous. I had to keep my legs up, my feet away from the important steering pedals, and my hands away from the many switches nearby. I decided that I would not relax and enjoy the flight, even though I knew I needed to stay calm and focused to survive the experience.

When we started speeding down the runway, I felt anxious. Dario, the pilot, and I were in the Zivko Edge 540, one of the fastest acrobatic planes in the world. The plane took off, and just two seconds later, we turned sharply to the right. I felt the air push out of my lungs. I looked at the horizon, tensed my body, and gasped as I sank into my seat. For a moment, I felt like I weighed 6.2 times my normal weight. Then we leveled out and made another sharp left turn, diving down. 

We were now just 10 meters above the ground, aiming for a small space between two pylons. We passed them at 400 km per hour, and I felt a rush of excitement, but then we made a quick right turn. I hadn’t even done any acrobatics yet. For two minutes, I was allowed to fly the plane, but my hand was shaking so much that the plane shook too. 

Then Dario said something, but I couldn’t hear him. Instead of answering, he did a barrel roll, turning the plane completely upside down. “Are you okay?” he asked. “Yes,” I replied. “Have you had enough?” “No,” I lied. Then he did a loop, flying up and over in a full circle. 

I know many people would find this exciting, like those who enjoy roller coasters. However, I thought it was too much for me. At the top of the loop, while we were upside down, I heard a voice saying, “Relax, relax, look up.” I looked up and saw some fields below us. The flight lasted 10 minutes, and it felt easy compared to what the pilots experience during the race. 

As soon as we landed, Dario took out some sandwiches and happily started eating. I didn’t eat for hours, and that night, I kept dreaming about doing loops in the air.

Doug Allan films wild animals in cold places. If you have ever been impressed by videos of polar bears in a nature documentary, it is likely that he filmed them. He says his ideal temperature is -18°C. Allan trained as a marine biologist and commercial diver. Diving was his first love, where he learned how to survive in cold environments. His big opportunity came when a TV crew arrived in Antarctica, where Allan was working, to make a wildlife documentary. "I ended up taking the crew to different locations, and after 48 hours, I realized that being a wildlife cameraman was perfect for me: travel, adventure, underwater," he explains. He is now a well-known cameraman and has worked on many important TV wildlife series. 

"I started at a good time. When I began, very few people had been to Antarctica. There were people who focused on coral, elephants, and chimpanzees. I became known as the cold man. It felt like there were so many amazing moments waiting to be filmed." The camera and communication technology were very basic when he started 35 years ago. "It is much easier to film today. Back then, if you shot something, you had to remember it. Now, with digital technology, you can film a lot and see it right away. You had to think about what shots you needed next and what you missed. You filmed less because film was very expensive. Today, you can have too much footage."

"My experience in cold conditions is valuable. I know how to handle it. I have spent so much time on sea ice that it feels as easy as crossing the street. I do get cold toes, but the poles are healthy places. There are no leeches, diseases, or mosquitoes." Allan says that wildlife filming has many successes, but also failures and embarrassing moments. Once, he was in the Orkneys to film kittiwakes, but he could not identify the birds.

Recently, Allan got permission to film for a major TV series in Kong Karls Land, a group of islands in the Arctic Ocean. He knew it would not be easy. It is a place for polar bears and is only for the bravest or most foolish. In April, it is usually -32°C, the wind is strong, and carrying cameras through deep snow is very difficult. After walking for five or more hours a day and watching polar bear dens in the snow for 23 days, Allan had only seen one mother bear and her cub. However, on day 24, he felt like he was in the world of bears, moving at their speed and sensing like them. 

"We find a new hole and wait. We shuffle, hop, bend, stretch, and run to stay warm. After five hours of watching, suddenly I see something so quick that I almost miss it. But the camera is focused on the hole, and my eye is on the viewfinder. Nothing happens for a couple of seconds, and then I see a black nose. The nose becomes a muzzle, then a full head, and in less than a minute, she has her front legs out and is resting on the snow in front of the hole. She looks at me but is not scared. I pull back from a close-up, thinking it can't get better, when she slides down the slope. I believe she is enjoying it," he recalls, adding that two cubs then appeared at the den entrance. "Clearly, it’s their first view of the world. It’s showtime on the slopes, and we have front-row seats."

Now, Allan wants to make his own film about climate change in the Arctic, talking to the people who live there and see its effects firsthand. He believes he could create an extraordinary documentary.

In 2004, Pen Hadow became the first person to walk to the North Pole alone without getting supplies along the way. This journey involved swimming in extremely cold water and facing dangers like frostbite and polar bears. Just eight months later, he reached the South Pole too. Now, he is back in the Arctic, getting ready for an even bigger adventure. Explorers like Pen are confident and determined. This time, however, there is much more at stake. Pen and two colleagues will go on a three-month, 1,000-kilometre journey to the North Pole to measure the thickness and density of the ice. No one has done this before, and he knows the results will be very important for scientists. This research will show how global warming is affecting the ice in the polar regions.

Pen was prepared for this work from a young age. His father’s old nanny, who had worked for the famous polar explorer Scott of the Antarctic, helped toughen him up. She would send him out into the Scottish mountains during storms with very few clothes. His father also inspired his love for adventure, and Pen developed great physical strength. Pen is married to Mary, who loves horses and shares his passion for the outdoors. She helps run his polar guide business and worries more about him when he is at home. She once raced against him in a mountain event and finished an hour ahead of him. 

Pen and Mary live in the countryside with their two children. He finds it harder to be away from them this time. When he last left, his son was only one year old, and he made a mistake in saying goodbye. He told his son to take care of his mother and sister, which put too much pressure on the boy. This time, Pen plans to have little contact with his family while he is in the Arctic because he believes that calling them will remind them of how far away he is. 

In the days before he leaves, he is carefully preparing his equipment. He knows that once he is on the ice, it will be very difficult to fix anything. He will be joined by Ann Daniels, a leading polar explorer, and Martin Hartley, the expedition photographer. They will have a support team of six people who will fly in supplies. Pen feels that being part of a team can be stressful for him, and he is also worried about his age. He will turn 47 soon and feels he has not trained enough. He admits that he has been busy with planning and is concerned about what he will be able to do.

Pen believes that his mission connects exploration with the search for knowledge, just like explorers in the past. He says that reaching the North Pole was a personal goal, but this time, the data they collect will help scientists and engage more people in understanding what is happening in the Arctic Ocean. He feels that their unique skills are now very important and useful to society again.

Text: "I took a 'year off'. What was I going to do? Being a successful Olympian is a wonderful experience. I had the opportunity to do more writing and TV work, and to speak to businesses and schools. Although I enjoyed these activities, I felt there was nothing competitive to focus on. I wanted to stay in shape so I could compete for an Olympic spot if I felt inspired again. So, I signed up for marathons and triathlons. That should have been enough, but I kept thinking about TV presenter Ben Fogle’s invitation: 'Do you want to row across the Atlantic with me?' I have always loved rowing and the feeling of the boat moving through the water. I missed that feeling, but I wasn’t ready to train every day. Still, I wanted some kind of competition. I asked some of my rowing friends if they wanted to join the race, but they weren’t very excited. I knew that if I entered the race, even though it was called an adventure, I would want to win. Would rowing with Ben give me the best chance to win? No. But being an underdog without pressure was appealing. I contacted Ben. He was going to join the race anyway and had managed to gather the large entry fee and deposit for a boat, making the race a real possibility. We discussed the costs; the boat and equipment would cost £70,000, which is a lot of money. We thought we had a better chance than most, but it would still require effort to secure it. Besides the race costs, I also had to think about the money I would lose by being away from home. Speaking at business conferences is one of the best ways to earn money as a retired athlete. It feels good that people are interested. However, I find it hard to talk about my past achievements without having a new goal. Joining the race would mean I wouldn’t just talk about what I did before; I would actually be doing something again: rowing across the Atlantic. I learned a lot while planning this adventure, but one of the biggest lessons was to appreciate the easy life of a full-time athlete. My preparation for the Olympics was tough, and my life was focused on getting in the best shape; but looking back, it was quite simple. Yes, I trained almost every day, but the training program was organized, and there were doctors and dieticians. I was worried about how people would react to me racing with a TV presenter. I thought it might look like I just wanted to be on TV, and I could have chosen a better partner to win the race. However, my worries faded as we prepared. The Atlantic Rowing Race is about more than just rowing; it’s also about mental strength. Ben had completed the difficult Marathon des Sables, spent a lot of time at sea, and lived on a deserted island for a year. But he couldn’t row well. I was surprised by how little he understood about rowing, and he was surprised by my lack of patience. I could have been more understanding, but I felt it was important to tell Ben how much he needed to improve. I should have realized that this was his level when I agreed to race with him."

Text: 

Just over a year ago, I left my job to work with huskies in the Arctic Circle in northern Finland. At 26, I felt restless and dreamed of cold, empty landscapes, maybe because I was tired of the busy life in London. I found a small company run by Anna McCormack and her husband, Pasi Ikonen, in Finnish Lapland. They offered me a job as a husky dog handler for the busy winter season. From December to February, they take many tourists on sled rides pulled by huskies across the snow and ice, for trips that can last from one hour to five days. They started with six dogs, but now they have more than 100. Recently, they took over a second place called the 'wilderness farm,' which they described as a beautiful but basic location with unreliable electricity and no running water. They told me I could join the team for three months, but I needed to know what I was getting into. "The hours are long, the conditions are tough, and the work is very physical," they said. I started packing right away.

November 6, London

On my flight, I stared at a page with over 100 pictures of huskies. I was supposed to memorize their names, but I felt distracted and nervous. I put the page down and looked out the window instead. I remembered that spring moves north at about 26 km per day, bringing flowers and leaves. But now, I saw winter moving south, and the rivers were freezing.

November 7, Helsinki and Hetta

The bus ride north was everything I hoped for. We drove through endless dark forests with thin trees covered in snow, stopping sometimes to let reindeer pass. I arrived at the farm after dark, and as soon as I walked in, I was given a pair of boots and sent out into the cold. "Do you want to be thrown in at the deep end?" Anna asked. It was a rhetorical question. I followed the sound of barking, which grew louder as I reached the dogsheds. Three people were running back and forth, pulling the huskies out and harnessing them to sleds. The dogs were very excited, straining against their ropes. I could barely introduce myself, but the others were too busy to talk. I stood to the side and petted one of the quieter dogs. Someone waved at me impatiently, saying, "Get in!" I almost fell into the nearest sled. A command was shouted, and suddenly we were off into the dark, with only a headlamp for light.

November 15, Hetta

It didn’t take long for me to become part of the husky guides, but first, I faced a tough questioning about what I could do for the group. "Are you useful?" Anna asked. I was confused. I didn’t know. Further questions showed that I was not very useful: I had never driven a snowmobile, hadn’t done woodwork since school, and had never chopped anything with an axe. "You do have a driving license?" someone asked finally. I nodded, feeling relieved. 

I learned the basics of dog-sledding quickly: lean into the corners, put both feet on the brake to stop, and, no matter what, don’t let go of the handlebar. But everything else seemed complicated. Simple tasks like feeding and watering the dogs became hard in freezing conditions. A bowl of water would freeze quickly, so we had to make a 'soup' of meat in hot water for the dogs. By the end of my first week, my head was full of instructions, and my muscles ached from pulling heavy sleds and being pulled around by excited huskies. But I felt proud. "I can chop with an axe, hammer a nail, and use a circular saw," I emailed my friends. "In the snow."

On that day, as Radcliffe ran past the finish line, reporters gathered to understand her amazing performance. They noted that her time was fast enough to qualify for the men's marathon at the world championships in Paris. Curious journalists asked her about a special natural treatment called emu oil, which Olympic gold medallist Cathy Freeman had suggested to help Radcliffe recover from an injury caused by an accident when she ran into a bike while training. Radcliffe said that the achievement didn’t fully hit her at the time. Looking back, she realizes it was a significant moment, but she felt it was just what she was meant to do that day. She and her team had decided not to set any limits on their goals, following the motto: no limits.

During the race, Gary Lough, Radcliffe's husband and coach, was in a car with her support team, listening to the radio coverage. Gerard Hartmann, her physiotherapist, was also with him. After 16 kilometers, Radcliffe's agent wondered if she could maintain her fast pace, fearing she might have to drop out. Hartmann was upset by this concern, although he understood that someone who didn’t know how fit she was might think it was risky to start so quickly. With 800 meters left, Radcliffe started to calculate her finish time. She realized she could finish in under 2 hours and 16 minutes if she crossed the line in less than three minutes. After running 41 kilometers at a fast speed, she managed to sprint the last part in 2 minutes and 25 seconds. At the finish, she thought, “I can run faster than that.” She remembered the race director, Dave Bedford, saying he never thought anyone would come close to that time for a long time, and she thought, “I will come back and do it next year.” Unfortunately, that did not happen.

After the race, everyone wanted to know how Radcliffe, who had an unusual running style, had beaten the skilled East African runners. Hartmann had worked closely with Radcliffe for weeks, providing daily training sessions to help her manage the 250-300 kilometers she ran each week. He said, “I’ve worked with 63 Olympic medallists, and no one could handle the level of pain she could. She would push me to my limits.” Hartmann described traveling 13 hours from his home in Ireland to Radcliffe's training base in France, only to be greeted by her husband saying, “Gerard, you’re 15 minutes late, Paula’s waiting.” There was no time for small talk; Radcliffe was ready for a two-hour training session. “Paula would get everything out of you. That’s what made her so good.” 

During this time, Hartmann dedicated so much of his time to Radcliffe that his other athletes became unhappy. When asked if she knew why no one has come close to her record, Radcliffe said, “Not really. I trained very hard, but there are more talented people out there. I thought Mary Keitany (a two-time London marathon winner) would do it.” She explained that maybe people are more focused on competing against each other than on improving themselves. “That mental attitude of never slowing down, even when you’re winning, probably helped me because I never thought, ‘I can relax now.’ It was always about pushing myself as hard as I could.” Radcliffe did not realize it at the time, but that marathon was the peak of her career. She would never run that fast again, but she inspired many women to take up long-distance running.

Text: "When my first cooking show, In Search of Perfection, was released, I was unsure how viewers and critics would react. At that time, there was a lot of talk about a 'food revolution' happening in Britain. I believed we had created a series that truly contributed to this movement, but I still worried: would people like a cooking show that included not just techniques but also history, memories, and science? I watched the first episode with mixed feelings of joy and fear. I didn’t need to worry. The success of the show led to many exciting projects, including a book about my experiences at my restaurant. Each project felt like a journey, whether into the past, the mind, or cooking techniques. I then wrote several books in a series called ‘Perfection’, each one linked to its own TV show. In these books, the journey was often physical, involving travel and exploration. 

The latest book, In Search of Total Perfection, takes you around the world to meet amazing artisans, like a man who creates golden pasta that tastes better than any other. These artisans have spent years pursuing their own ideas of perfection. Perfection is very personal. Even choosing which dishes to include in the series was difficult, and I knew I would disappoint some people by leaving out their favorites. I could imagine people asking, ‘Where’s steak and kidney pie and bread and butter pudding?’ However, after a long meeting with the TV production team, we finally created a list that included something for everyone. This experience reinforced my belief that each person has their own idea of perfection, shaped by their emotions, memories, and surroundings. 

Despite the book’s title, I knew I wouldn’t claim that the recipes were the ‘best’. I believed that by using my cooking skills and scientific knowledge, and by talking to food producers, artisans, chefs, and their customers, I could identify what made these dishes special. The dictionary defines ‘perfection’ as being perfect, but it also means improving through constant experimentation. This means trying out ideas and changing them until you create something unique. The TV series allowed me to explore many foods, people, and places I had never seen before, and I was excited to connect food with memories because I started my career in the same way. Finding the best ingredients took me around the world. I had many adventures, like visiting a canning factory that was processing the wrong type of tomato and going to a dairy farm that did not meet our standards for perfection, which made us stop filming there! While refining each recipe, I ended up hand-milking a cow and using dry ice to make ice cream, cooking chicken in a hospital scanning machine, and almost burning my house down trying to get the oven hot enough for a real Neapolitan-style pizza."

Text: 

We were still a long way from Marrakech when the van made a loud noise, swerved off the road into a field, and stopped. John got out and opened the engine cover. He looked at the engine for a long time with his hands in his pockets, looking serious. “Actually, I don’t know what I’m doing,” he finally said, and he and Mum started to laugh. Bea was worried, “We can’t stay here forever,” she said. The field was big and empty, just grass and many flowers like poppies and daisies. “No, we can’t stay here forever,” I agreed, because it was better to support Bea. We got back into the van and waited for Mum and John to stop laughing. We watched John get smaller as he walked away to find someone who could help with the van. Mum lay down on the grass. “Tell us a story,” she said. Bea lay down next to her. “Go on, tell us a story.” So I told them about how the day before we left London, I heard two birds talking. I shared everything they talked about: breadcrumbs, other birds, the weather, and an argument over a worm. “That’s silly, no one understands bird language,” Bea said. My eyes felt wet. “I do.” But I didn’t sound very sure. “Liar.” I felt embarrassed. How could I be lying if I remembered everything? The more I thought, the less sure I became. “Mum…?” But she had fallen asleep in the sun. 

John came back with three Moroccan boys who helped us push the van to the hotel. Bea didn’t want to get out. The boys didn’t mind; they waved and smiled at her through the back windows. We followed John into a café that was not far from where our van was parked. “It’s a hotel,” John whispered. “It might be a bit expensive.” “We’ll just have some tea,” Mum said, and we sat in the shade. The tea was made from mint leaves and was very sweet. Mum looked into the pot. “It’s like syrup,” she said. We stayed at the café all day while John looked sadly at the engine. “It’s a miracle it got us this far,” he said as it got dark. Mum took blankets out onto the road and made a bed for us in the hotel garden. It felt nice to sleep on the ground. “I’ll have to get us towed into Marrakech,” John said from the other side of Mum. 

Half an hour later, we were in a truck watching our van being pulled behind with John driving. At first, Bea didn’t want to move, so John picked her up and put her in the truck. Now she sat in the front with the driver. I kept thinking about how we would get home now that our van had to be towed. I thought it might be easier to take a boat straight to London. Then I must have fallen asleep.

Text: 

Lucy was at a welcome party in a hotel ballroom, talking to two other pianists who were also at the Prague Classical Music Festival. One was a guy from Tokyo, and the other was a girl from a European city named Liesel or Louisa. They were both about ten years older than Lucy and spoke good English. They discussed the music they were playing and their recent travels. 

“I think I'm doing Tanglewood this summer,” Lucy said. It sounded impressive, but she didn’t really want to go to the Tanglewood festival. She often felt overwhelmed by the concerts and competitions that took her around the world, making her miss so much school that she wasn’t officially enrolled anymore. Instead, she worked with tutors from the University of San Francisco. 

Lucy hadn’t even wanted to come to the Prague Festival, which only accepted fifteen pianists her age from around the world. She had been chosen from thousands of applicants. Her dad bought her a white-gold necklace with an L pendant to celebrate, and her little brother Gus dreamed of being at the same festival one day. Her teacher, Grace Chang, took her out for a special dinner to plan her music pieces. The truth was, Lucy hadn’t applied herself; her mother had filled out the form and sent in a CD. “I didn't want you to be disappointed if you didn’t get in,” her mom had said. Lucy thought her mom just didn’t want to let her say no. Back then, she believed that making waves was the worst thing to do, so she didn’t think about trying to get out of it.

The guy from Tokyo leaned in, surprised. “Tanglewood?” 

“Yeah.” 

“How old are you?” 

“Fifteen.” 

He looked at Liesel/Louisa, who said, “Wow.” Lucy hadn’t meant to brag. It was hard to know when she was just sharing her experiences or showing off. 

“It’s just part of this new youth-spotlight thing they’re trying...” 

“Excuse me,” Liesel/Louisa said, looking across the room as if she saw someone she needed to talk to. The guy from Tokyo stayed. “Have you ever been to Japan?” 

He had long, shaggy hair, like many musicians, to show they were cool but still loved music. 

“Once. When I was about eight.” He started to reply when Lucy's grandfather appeared beside her. 

“Lucy, let me introduce you to someone.” He took her arm and pulled her away from the conversation. “And don’t get too friendly with the competition.” 

“They're not the competition.” 

“Everyone is the competition.” 

Her grandfather took her around the room, making her talk to important people. Lucy smiled and nodded, understanding only part of what was said. 

In the elevator to their suite after the party, her grandfather said, “You did well in there, Lucy. I’m proud of you. This is an important festival, and people are talking about you. They all know who you are.” 

Lucy liked that. Being someone important. Even if some people were jealous or thought she was too young for the attention she got. Being a concert pianist didn’t earn her respect from the kids at school. Even her best friend, Reyna, didn’t know or care that she could play a difficult Rachmaninov piece. But in places like this, she felt she mattered.

Text: 

“It’s not good for you to spend so much time online. You need to get out into the real world,” said Dad. It’s hard to argue with him, so I decided to look into what experts say about this topic – and it’s quite interesting. Research shows that most teenagers who use social media have many real-life friends, a strong sense of identity, and are learning important technical skills for the digital world.

Simon Miles, an e-safety expert, says, “Social networking is now a big part of growing up. Teenagers don’t just use media like adults do; they live in it. This isn’t necessarily good or bad – it depends on how you use it.” 

How does our social networking compare to what our parents did when they were young? Jim Matthews, a social media analyst, says it’s like the modern version of hanging out at a youth club, where parents used to share jokes and gossip. He believes it helps teenagers build their identity away from their parents and learn to handle teenage issues with their friends.

Psychologist Professor Keith Davidson explains, “Adolescence is a time when you ask, ‘Who am I?’ Social networking can help you find your identity. You can share your favorite music or sports, discover what you like, and see that others have different opinions.” He adds that active social networkers are not as self-centered as those who don’t use social media. He believes that using social media can be easier for shy people: “Talking online can feel more comfortable than face-to-face, and it helps you practice social skills in a less stressful way.”

Professor Andrew Phillips is studying how young people use social networking sites. He thinks they can help quiet people with special interests connect with others who share those interests. “If you’re one of only a few people in your school who likes a certain type of music, you might feel alone. But if you find a social networking group of people like you, you can feel popular in a different way,” he says.

Pauline White, a digital education expert, shared something interesting: “It’s young people who find new interests online, join groups of similar individuals, and create their own content who are really using social networks well.” She believes social networking is becoming a creative tool: teenagers are making videos, podcasts, and blogs about what interests them. Photo-sharing sites are changing creativity, allowing photographers to connect, learn skills, share images, and deepen their interests. “This all helps with job opportunities and will be useful in the workplace,” she says. “Every business uses social media to sell and build brand awareness – and you need to know how it works to attract customers. For example, if you create a product and have 1,000 friends on different social networks, they could all be potential customers. If you connect all those networks, you have your customer base.”

Teenagers who use social networking creatively will benefit when they become adults and enter the job market, agrees Matthews. “One great thing about many sites is the chance to work with others to create content and share it. Collaboration is an important skill in the 21st century and is essential for being employable in a digital world.”

Text: 

When most people think of a relaxing family vacation, they might not imagine a long trip across nine western states in the US and a Canadian province. However, my parents were not looking for a quiet time when they planned our summer vacation this year. My dad seemed determined to create what he thought would be the perfect family bonding experience. “Not enough people do this anymore,” he and my mother said repeatedly before our trip, while my twin brother and I exchanged worried looks, thinking, “There are probably good reasons for that!”

In mid-June, we packed our car with suitcases, coolers, and a mix of clothes for any weather. I was excited but knew I would miss my privacy for the next two weeks. Still, I had some ideas to cope. With barely enough space left for us in the car, we began “The Family Great American Road Trip.” Leaving our big home for smaller places for the next five thousand miles made me wonder what we were getting into.

We drove west through the Oklahoma panhandle. Even though we were still close to home, we had our share of adventures. We stopped for the night near a town in Oklahoma, under a sky full of stars, after almost being blown off the road by a dust storm. We quickly learned that cattle have the right-of-way on the road!

The next day, we woke up early and continued our journey. I noticed a pattern: deserts turned into mountains. The days started to blend together, but each adventure was still unique. We left our footprints in the Great Sand Dunes and then went to Pagosa Springs, Colorado, where we noticed a strong smell of sulfur. As we climbed to our next stop, we learned that roads marked for Jeeps are best for Jeep drivers.

Everywhere we stopped, we saw a mix of old and new. Dealing with construction traffic became normal. We laughed when we took pictures next to the big “CLOSED” signs at the Four Corners Monument. We passed many wind farms on our way to Yellowstone National Park, where we watched the sunset over bear habitats near the roads. “Bear jams,” where traffic stops to let bears cross, were common, and our close encounter with a bear (and a worried park ranger) gave us unforgettable memories.

As we drove, life back home faded away. Even the hotel we stayed in, which was old and had no internet or cell phone service, couldn’t dampen our excitement. In return for these inconveniences, I got to see the most beautiful views I’ve ever experienced. After watching a rainstorm from our cozy hotel in Canada, my family and I headed back south. My parents were right: you don’t need to travel to a faraway place to find something amazing. 

It was a bit sad to be home again, but at least I hadn’t fought with my brother during our one hundred hours on the road! We had three thousand photos from our crazy journey to look through. I knew that the memories I would cherish most would be the unexpected and spontaneous moments.

Rose Frost was sixteen years old and was going to live with her grandmother, Daisy. Rose's family was separating for two years. Her father, Jeff, had a job overseas, and her mother, Dahlia, would join him. Rose and her older sister, Amy, were staying in England. Amy would spend the next year finishing her last school courses, living under the care of the college Head. It was her final year at school, so it would not be fair for her to move. Amy was happy because she got the best room at the college, which had its own kitchen and study area. She also had free access to the Internet and phone. Jeff and Dahlia would keep an eye on Amy, whether she liked it or not. So, Rose was moving to her grandmother’s house. 

Rose only had vague memories of her grandmother from holidays, and she had never known her grandfather. When Daisy offered Rose a place to stay, her parents were not excited about it, but Daisy insisted it was no trouble and was happy to get to know Rose again. Rose was not sure why her parents did not get along with her grandma, but there had been a disagreement in the past, which meant Rose spent summers away from her only other family member. Rose was only ten years old when she last said goodbye, but she remembered those times as happy. Dahlia said living with Daisy would be interesting. Daisy was very social and had a talent for bringing people together. Rose could expect dinner invitations, coffee mornings, and shopping trips soon, which made her smile. Daisy was not a typical frail old lady; she seemed to go to more social events than anyone else.

Before the move, Dahlia and Rose had a serious talk. Rose was sensible and mature for her age. She knew about healthy eating, staying fit, and getting enough sleep. But this time, Rose insisted on one thing: she wanted her independence. Living with Daisy would meet her needs, but Rose wanted to play music loudly, invite friends over, and go out without asking for permission every time. She believed she could be trusted to do these things. She didn’t want to be reminded about homework or staying out late, and she didn’t want to be taken around by her grandmother. Daisy understood. Rose’s mother gave her a new touch-screen mobile phone with a video camera for emergencies only, which made Rose very happy. They all agreed it would be about trust. Daisy would trust Rose to act maturely, and Rose would trust Daisy not to be too controlling. If either of them crossed a line, they would talk about it again.

Rose had never been a wild child. Her few school friends were similar, so her school reports were always good, and her exam results were excellent. This helped her a lot. In five weeks, Rose would start at a new school, meet new friends, and begin her life again. This was her fourth senior school in five years, so she felt experienced. At least she knew this would be the last time, as she would be starting her final two years at school. For Rose, it was a new moment in her life, a new piece in the puzzle that was her life.

Charlotte Grainger shares that her primary school teacher was the first person to think she might write a novel. She says, “I believed that writing a book would be a great achievement because it seemed very challenging. I didn’t know what other teenagers were doing, like competing in the Olympics. When I turned 13, I thought, ‘I should try this now.’” The novel she started at that age is now about to be published. She recently told her former teacher about it, and the teacher was surprised. The teacher had thought Charlotte would write a book when she was 30 or 40, but Charlotte never considered waiting that long. 

It is a winter afternoon in the offices of Charlotte’s publishers. Even though I knew I was going to interview a 15-year-old girl about her book, I was surprised to see a teenager sitting there. The book is a significant achievement: it has a strong and exciting story. The only thing that shows it was written by a teenager is the age of the main character. A public relations representative is with us in case Charlotte needs help, but she doesn’t. She is confident, smart, and steady, which keeps her from being overly confident.

Charlotte understands that she is still young. When I ask her about the complex moral questions in her book, she says, “I was trying to ask big questions, not answer them. I don’t have many life lessons to share with my readers.” She laughs and adds, “I don’t think my age limits my understanding of the world, but I also don’t think I’m very wise. I just wanted to explore the idea of taking responsibility.”

Charlotte has a theory about how teenagers are often misrepresented in books aimed at them. She believes there are three types of teenagers in novels: the outsider who becomes accepted, the naïve teenager who knows little about the world, and the socially awkward teenager. She finds it frustrating to read about these types. “What if you’re basically fine? There aren’t many stories about characters who are not inadequate in some way. Some writers unintentionally suggest that teenagers can’t know who they are because they lack experience, and that can hurt their self-confidence.”

Charlotte has always loved reading famous fantasy authors, but their books almost discouraged her from writing. “My favorite fantasy writers explore deep topics about psychology and life. I wondered if I needed to write like that to create a good book and if I was capable of doing it.” However, she appreciates a book called How Not to Write a Novel, which teaches that if readers can guess what will happen next, the suspense is likely gone.

Some might say that Charlotte’s parents, both journalists, played a key role in getting her novel published. Her father’s connection in publishing helped her book get read initially. She recognizes her good luck because it is hard for anyone to get a first novel read, regardless of their age. “Every aspiring writer needs support and a bit of luck, but after that, you are on your own. Ultimately, writers succeed or fail based on their talent, so I don’t take anything for granted,” Charlotte concludes.

Text: 

“Remember, speed is your friend, not your enemy,” said Gareth, our instructor, as we looked down the ski slope. “Now, who wants to go first?” The group looked nervous. Then David, who had some experience with freestyle ski-jumping, stepped forward and skied down the slope towards the jump. He went fast and flew into the air, but something seemed wrong. We held our breath. He landed hard, losing both skis, and fell into the snow. “Remember,” Gareth said kindly, “speed can be unpredictable.” 

I started to think that maybe freestyle skiing wasn’t for me. On previous skiing holidays, I had enjoyed practicing turns in the snow. I wasn’t like those teenagers who did tricks on ramps and half pipes in skate parks. I thought it looked fun, but I was afraid of looking silly if I tried to join them. Then my parents decided we would have a winter holiday at a training center for freestyle skiing in the US. The center had a big indoor area with trampolines and ski jumps covered in artificial snow. Students practiced their tricks and landed in foam pits, which was not a realistic way to prepare for the real slopes. 

After practicing indoors, we went outside to try our skills. “Progression is inevitable!” the center’s slogan said. “Before places like this trained people, inexperienced ski jumpers would just throw themselves down the slopes and hope for the best,” Gareth explained. “But remember – if you land on the knuckle, you’ll be in trouble.” The “knuckle” is the flat area behind the jump before the slope goes down to the landing zone. If you land in the zone, you keep moving forward, which is safer. If you land on the flat, you stop suddenly, which can hurt. So, speed is important.

At first, it was hard for me to ignore my fear and go fast towards the jump. My legs seemed to slow down as I got closer, and I landed on the knuckle. I didn’t fall, but by midday, I felt exhausted. “You need to control the jump, not let it control you,” Gareth said. 

On the second day, we started on the trampolines. I thought I would hate being indoors, but bouncing on the trampolines was fun. Some exercises copied the moves we would make while ski-jumping, and others helped us learn “aerial awareness” – understanding what our bodies were doing while in the air. Gareth gave us tips. My “aerial awareness” needed improvement – every time I tried, I only remembered the moment before take-off and then found myself in the foam cubes next to the trampoline. 

We went back to the mountain to try again. There were more mistakes, but eventually, I landed properly. Gareth was as happy as I was, and for a moment, I felt proud of my achievement. But that feeling didn’t last long. On my last run of the day, I made myself keep my speed up as I approached the jump, flew into the air, and landed correctly. Then I saw both skis sliding down the slope ahead of me, no longer attached to my feet.

Text: 'Imagine you are on a rollercoaster in an amusement park. Your palms are sweaty with fear, and your nails are digging into the safety harness. The ride suddenly stops, and you take a deep breath as the carriage slowly moves upwards. There is a pause, then a sharp drop that makes your stomach feel like it is in the air. You quickly move forward, turn sharply to the left, and then go upside down. Your senses are overwhelmed, and you let out a scream of fear. But you chose to be here, just like millions of others who pay to enter theme parks each year. 

What is interesting to me is that amusement parks, with their thrilling rides, are a big business. To create the excitement and escape from reality that visitors want, there are large teams of creative engineers, designers, and marketing experts working behind the scenes. The idea of being a 'rollercoaster designer' might sound like a childhood dream, but it is actually a difficult job. Designers must find the right mix of fun and fear while keeping passengers safe. They also need to introduce new ideas to keep visitors coming back. 

While many people think that rollercoasters have become more intense over time, most of the techniques used today, like the wheels that allow rides to go upside down, were invented by a US designer named John Miller in the early 1900s. During his time, rollercoasters were very extreme, which made some passengers uncomfortable. Now, designers have to follow the track designs provided by special ride manufacturers.

I spoke to three experts about rollercoasters. Professor Brendan Walker, a 'thrill engineer' with a background in aeronautics, said, 'The skill is in putting the pieces together.' Dr. John Roberts, a member of the Royal Academy of Engineering, explained that this means quickly switching between feelings of excitement and safety, so people feel thrilled but not scared. 

To create an amazing ride, the teams behind rollercoasters must develop a strong story, like a space adventure or a fast jungle chase, that works with new features like the tallest rides or steepest drops to create a smooth experience. However, Professor Walker noted that, like in many creative fields, intuition, experience, and trial-and-error are very important. Jeff Hornick, a senior director of theme park development, agreed, saying that it helps to be passionate about thrills to understand what passengers want and to test rides before they open to the public.

I asked the experts if rollercoaster designers would need to use new technology, like virtual reality. Walker said we should not expect too much from it. 'Virtual reality can add some excitement, but it is like painting an old rollercoaster beautifully,' he said. 'New technology appears all the time, and parks quickly adopt it because it is exciting and can enhance the ride experience. But the real physical experience of the coaster will remain the most important part for many years to come.'

At 25, Miranda Ellington has already done a lot as a choreographer, creating performances for many theatres and dance companies. She also dances occasionally. I wonder why she manages to do both activities in her busy life. She explains, “Dancing again reminds me of what it’s like to be in the studio, following the orders of strict choreographers, and how stressful that can be. Choreographers can forget what it feels like to rehearse all day.”

As a choreographer, she teaches and enjoys working with young dancers. “A beginner dancer is often open to trying new ideas. In some ways, it’s easier to work with students than with professionals because they are willing to take risks. They want to succeed, but they don’t yet know their strengths and weaknesses. This lack of understanding helps them accept even tough criticism. Sometimes they challenge what I say, but I appreciate their honest feedback.”

When Miranda starts with a new group, she focuses on the dance steps, and the music guides her. “There might be music I don’t like, but I still create the best dance routine for it. If dancers don’t respond well to a certain piece of music, it can be frustrating, but I have to find solutions. I can’t just choose a new piece of music. I wish I could be more experimental and switch to different pieces, as it would help improve the mood during tough rehearsals. Unfortunately, I often work on large productions where the music is already decided and cannot be changed.”

Miranda believes in making connections with new people. “It’s important to meet new people, but I have to remember that each theatre and school has different methods and styles. I need to adapt my way of working each time I go somewhere new, instead of just doing the same thing. This helps me avoid becoming too set in my ways.”

We discuss a recent documentary about professional ballet dancers and choreographers. “There have been glamorous documentaries in the past that were misleading,” Miranda says. “This one tries to show the real life inside a dance company. There’s a scene where a young dancer is getting many corrections, and I smiled because I recognized that feeling. She knows she’s not getting it right but can’t make her body do what’s needed. It’s hard to watch, but it’s real. People often underestimate the work and dedication needed in ballet.”

I ask Miranda what makes a great dance production. “It’s when everything the company has worked on – the music, costumes, lighting, and dancers – comes together. Perfection might be too much to expect, but aiming high is appreciated by audiences and can help cover up a few mistakes. I’ve been part of productions where the dance steps are great, but something about the costumes or props is distracting, and that’s disappointing.”

Miranda has done many different types of work, so I ask how she sees herself: is she a modern dance choreographer or a ballet specialist? “People want to label you, and I don’t understand that. There’s a trend to focus on becoming an expert in a narrow area. I don’t follow that, but maybe one day I will be happy to be known for one thing. For now, I just want to explore more.”

Text: "A friend once asked me why I travel when I can see everything on television. I agreed that there are amazing things on TV, but why stay at home when there is so much to experience outside? This conversation inspired my unusual four-day trip and a film that encourages people to turn off their TVs. A friend was getting rid of his old sofa, which became the main focus of the film. I added three wheels and some cables to it and used old seatbelts to carry it. I put my luggage on the sofa and slept on it each night, even one night on the beach. Some friends joined me, helping to pull the sofa and motivating me to keep going. I have done many walking trips in recent years, but this was very different. It was the longest distance I have ever walked, and I walked on main roads, which allowed me to stop at cafés and enjoy a cappuccino on the sofa instead of eating sandwiches on a rock. I often had to tell people, “No, I’m not doing this for charity, and I’m not training for a marathon.” When someone at work asks about my weekend, I prefer to share how I dragged a sofa 100 miles across southern England rather than talk about the latest TV show. You can watch the film on my website."

Text: "When I read about guided swimming trips around some small Greek islands, I felt excited. I had never tried organized group trips before. My brother, who I usually travel with, was busy, so I thought a group holiday might be a good idea. The man at the Greek port looked surprised when I asked for a single ferry ticket, as the islands are popular with families. I explained that I wouldn’t be alone for long; I would be joining ten others to swim around the small islands. Although he still looked confused, he smiled and showed me on board.

Our group had exchanged emails before we started, but there was little time to talk before our first swim. Our guides explained that a support boat would follow us the whole time and made sure we knew how to communicate with it. We did a short swim to divide us into speed groups, and then it was time for our first proper swim of 1.5 km. I was nervous. I had trained in my local pool and done some river swimming, but I had never swum long distances in the open sea. Soon, the waves got bigger, and I found myself at the back of the slow group, which was not where I wanted to be. I watched the faster swimmers move ahead like dolphins. However, I wanted to finish this first distance, and I was very happy when I finally did it on my own.

The next days followed a routine: jumping in, finding a comfortable speed, and stopping to enjoy the scenery. As the swims got longer, my speed and enjoyment also increased. I felt like I didn’t need the support boat much anymore. I can hardly wait to come back again next year."

Text: "Being a flight attendant is not easy, but it has many rewards. Since I started this job, I have traveled to many places, from the US to Australia. I work with amazing people, have plenty of time off, and my life is always interesting, which makes it a great job for someone young like me! 

As a child, I went to a boarding school far from my family, so I often flew alone when school started and ended. Sometimes I felt lonely, so I would ask the flight attendants if I could help serve meals to passengers, and some of them let me. This experience stayed in my mind when I wanted to leave my banking job and find a new path.

At the interview for the flight attendant position, there were many young people, and many of us were hired. Most of us had good qualifications and were changing careers. Before the interview, I practiced what to say. I didn’t just say I loved to travel, like everyone else. Instead, I talked about my skills and past work experience, and that helped me get the job!

I would recommend this job to anyone because there are many benefits, but the free flights are not the best part. Most airline staff work very hard, and there is a saying: 'no one is finished until everyone is finished.' It feels like a big family. Even if we don’t see each other all the time, we are still close. When I’m not working, I don’t have to take my job home with me. If I do have to deal with difficult passengers, which is rare, I know the flight will end soon, and I probably won’t see them again!"

At the summer camp where I work, I really enjoy seeing the children succeed at things they never thought they could do. Most of the children already know how to swim and play table tennis before they arrive, but rock climbing is a new experience for many of them. Some children feel nervous at first, but with encouragement, they agree to try, and in the end, they all reach the top. This makes them feel great.

At the beginning of the week, some children miss home. It is not the youngest ones who feel this way the most; it is usually the ten- to thirteen-year-olds. We do not allow them to use their mobile phones all the time. First, we tell them they can call home after lunch. When they ask again, usually after dinner, we say it is too late to call now and suggest they do it tomorrow. Most children feel better in a couple of days, and by the end of their week, they all come to us and thank us because they have had a great time.

It is not only the children who feel lonely. We also have parents who call often to ask how their child is doing, which is not really necessary. Often, their child is busy playing games or doing other activities, so we have to tell the parents to call back later. We sometimes get children who come dressed in expensive new clothes. These children often argue when we ask them to change into something more suitable, but soon they understand why it is important.

Text: 'Rock the Planet is a musical show where the actors also need to be good musicians. It opened in London last year after being in the USA for five years, where it won the title of ‘Best Musical’ four times! However, putting on the show with an all-British cast was not easy. The UK has more rules about how many performances young actors can do each week compared to the USA, where they can do more shows. Because of this, they needed twice as many actors in the UK. Fortunately, the director found many talented actors in the UK, and they have just won their first ‘Best Musical’ award. 

The theatre in London is bigger than the one in the USA, and it has been full every night, with many people wanting to hear the songs that became popular in America. I met Jamie, an 11-year-old actor in the show. He said, ‘It’s amazing that I get paid to play, especially with a beautiful and expensive Gibson guitar.’ He shared how busy the young actors are. ‘We have regular school lessons at the theatre. The teacher is great, but I miss my old school friends.’ 

What do his friends think of the show? ‘My whole class came! The theatre offers special ticket deals for schools. They loved it, and that made me feel really confident. My parents come when they can, but it’s expensive for them,’ he explained. When I mentioned that I also play guitar, Jamie found a spare one and invited me to play with him and the other young actors. We played a song called Days, which I didn’t know. Jamie helped me learn it, and I felt proud when I finally got it right. I was impressed by Jamie’s talent and wished I had similar skills. I was just trying to keep up and was glad the show’s director wasn’t there to hear my mistakes! 

Although the young actors were already musicians, some playing several instruments, none had played in a band before. Luckily, they found it quite easy. Jamie said that the hardest part was looking natural when they first performed together. They were so focused that they forgot to smile! The show will be in London for another year, and it is definitely worth seeing.'
